review_text: I almost didn't want to watch this picture, sure Matt Damon and Ben Affleck have some great collaborative pictures together, but I'm not wholly impressed by some of the trash Netflix originals throw out. So to my surprise, I was really entertained by this neat little thriller.

No doubt Ben and Matt had fun making this film. It's a slick looking film from the outside but the script is just too absurd. So many decisions whilst still in the drug house make no sense and the accusing each other just gets tiresome half way through.

The Rip has the bones of an interesting story, but it's directed with the finesse of someone trying to paint while wearing oven gloves. There are flashes of potential in the premise and a few moments that hint at what the film could have been, but they're buried under clumsy pacing, awkward staging, and baffling creative choices. It's especially frustrating given the quality of the cast, who clearly have the talent to deliver something far better than what ends up on screen.

Surprisingly competent and watchable but fundamentally mediocre. The performances - especially from Damon and Affleck - are the biggest reason to sit through it; they inject texture into otherwise familiar genre scaffolding. As a thriller, it does enough to hold attention, but it rarely transcends its ingredients. The script's reliance on cliché and uneven character work keep it from being sharp. I genuinely think it's one of the better Netflix crime originals of recent years in terms of craft, yet obviously it doesn't meaningfully remake the genre or leave a distinct imprint. In raw terms: a solid genre fare with good acting, middling narrative ambition, and scattered execution, decent to watch once, forgettable in the long run.
The Rip is a very good cop thriller with a great tense first hour but loses some steam in the third act. It wins no awards for originality but wears it's B movie origins with pride.

1st act got me intrigued, 2nd act got me on the edge of my seat. 3rd act had me a little disapointed. Overall not a bad movie, but also not a memorable one either. I found that the writers did well building suspense through the first 2/3rds but failed to pay off the viewers with a very generic final action sequence that felt rushed and bland. Chemistry and acting skills of Damon and Affleck carry the movie giving it more appeal than it otherwise would have.

I was pretty excited And very interested on how good this would be. It definitely didn't let me down, I thought it had good pace twists and turns and a solid ending. I enjoyed it from the start to the finish, the acting and casting were cool choices also enjoyed the characters a lot personally.

The rip is nothing really new under the sun or anything that we really didn't watch before at some stage but it is without a doubt a solid thriller with a good pace, some cool twists and a very good action dose which makes the film a quite watchable one.

An entirely okay film, with plenty of action. Not the strongest script. Affleck and Damon perform well as usual, but the film itself is not among the best they have appeared in. A decent weekend movie, but not something you feel like rewatching anytime soon. The pacing is solid and keeps things moving, even when the story lacks depth. Overall, it works as light entertainment, but it does not leave a lasting impression.

This is a top quality police thriller. It is so well crafted and so well executed I was sick to my stomach from minute 1 until the end. The acting by Everyone is this is fantastic. Matt Damon and Ben Affleck have Never been this good together. Kyle Chandler, Steve Yuen, Teyana. Taylor, and Catalina Moreno. Love Scott Adkins. The Direction is superior. Netflix hit a grand slam on this.

Matt Damon and Ben Affleck bring far more presence than this film knows how to handle. Damon hints at a damaged, conflicted man whose inner life the script never bothers to explore, while Affleck's swagger suggests a volatile dynamic that never truly materializes. Instead of letting their relationship drive the tension, the film leans on a predictable twist and a formulaic structure that keeps everything safely on the surface. Even the action, which should be the backbone of a movie like this, feels tame and forgettable. It all goes down easily enough, but scene after scene you can feel the more ambitious, more engaging version of this story slipping away.

The Rip (2026) presents itself with a stylish surface and a concept that initially feels intriguing. The setup promises tension and emotional depth, and visually the film knows how to create a moody atmosphere.

Nothing wrong with this one. Decent movie with a advanced camera work and a decent plot. Nobody is doing anything particularly interesting nor is it very dull. But the budget is reported at 100
Million! But for what? These action flicks were done for 10 million a decade ago and now budgets exploding but the quality of the product is not. Not sure that is sustainable. Good news: at least one decent movie Netflix has been releasing recently!

It's crucial to understand that the narrative is rooted in actual events, highlighting how intertwined our realities are with the darker aspects of society. The undeniable influence of money over various facets of life demonstrates that even those sworn to protect and serve, like your next policeman, can succumb to corruption. This perspective serves as a reminder to remain vigilant and critical of those in power and the systems they operate within. Recognizing these truths is essential for fostering a more just and transparent society.

I'm surprised this went straight to Netflix. Despite the top notch actors, I fully expected this movie to be of "straight-to" quality in terms of story and editing. Instead, we get a really decent story that my husband and I found compelling and easy to watch. Definitely not a bad way to spend a couple hours.

Great to see Damon and Affleck back together - honestly their chemistry hits in every scene. That being said, not much original with the story, which is what i was expecting. In short its a great watch with some surprises but feel like this story has been told a 1000 times. Similar Carnahan blueprint, which means if you like he's other movies, you'll like this e.g. Alpha males and funny sayings. All actors are good in this btw.

Saw this on Netflix and started watching it the story line is incredible the movie is no where near what you would expect the cast is good the way the movie plays out the lighting and recording of the film is also great personally I believe it needs a lot more hype

Cast: phenomenal
Direction: solid
Script: ummmmmm...
It starts poorly. There's a lot you have to swallow to buy into this. Mood, camera angles, ominous soundtrack can only cover up so much.

There are a few good scenes, and the lead actors give it their all. But overall, the movie struggles to find its focus. It wants to be deep and explosive at the same time, and in trying to do both, it ends up being a bit dull and drawn out. Watchable, yes - but not unforgettable.

This is one of the first big budget films of 2026 that tries to hard, WAY TOO HARD to be something interesting, but falls short. Damon does his best to pull in the audience and keep some sort of suspense happening but as soon as Affleck hits the screen with his over acting and mumbling of lines, the big budget thriller turns into a second rate flick. If only they would have used Pablo Pasqual or Brad Pitt, Mark Wahlberg or even Mark Ruffalo.

In 2025, Danny Boyle resurrected the '28 Days Later' franchise with '28 Years Later', a bold addition that split audiences straight down the middle. Plenty of viewers embraced its ambition and found it a gripping, atmospheric return to the Rage-infected world, but others were far less convinced. For some, the film's bleak mood felt oppressive, its runtime indulgent and its somewhat restrained approach to gore a disappointing departure from the series' feral energy.

Danny Boyle's return to the world of the Rage virus, turned out to be a welcome one. Last year's journey into a quarantined Britain, penned by Alex Garland, offered unnerving scares, disgusting violence and thoughtful storytelling. Carried by stellar performances, 28 Years Later brought new life to this twist on the "Undead" genre. The final scene of that film however, gave it's sequel a steep hill to climb. Could The Bone Temple, solidify that bold, tonal shift of an ending, into a satisfying chapter of the Rage Virus story? Admittedly, I was a bit worried. I chose to set aside my personal wishes for this story and cast aside all expectations. Thankfully, I was rewarded with a courageous, insane and frankly, unhinged film.

I love how each 28 Days/Years movie focuses on different aspects and themes. This one involving cults, religion and philosophical elements added in with meaner, weirder and bolder ideas that keep things fresh. Danny Boyle's flair may not be present or the original music composers, but Nia DaCosta delivers her own flavour and take of a nicely shot and clean approach to the franchise's look and feel. It's also a much smaller scale movie than the previous ones, and that makes it way more focused and in my opinion far better paced and handled in most regards.

Absolutely loved this chapter of the story. Alex Garland and Danny Boyle's influence still pulses through the film, even under a new director. The Samson/Kelso relationship was genuinely magical, and I was deeply moved by the way their story was told. The dancing sequences and music choices had me smiling from ear to ear and laughing a few times. I can't recommend this enough. I was already a super fan, but this film completely hit the spot, one of my favourite cinema trips ever.

I went in hopeful but cautious - and honestly, '28 Years Later: The Bone Temple' is so good. It doesn't coast on nostalgia or try to out-shock the originals for the sake of it. It feels confident, strange, and properly alive. From the opening moments it's tense, trippy, and relentlessly unsettling in that very '28 Days' way - you're on edge the whole time, but never bored.

I loved this movie. Everything leading up to the ending was great. It was enjoyable, entertaining and most importantly fun but it is in the ending that the movie really shines. The ending was perfect. The movie is filled with nasty violence and a new side of the franchise is explored. Faith versus fear and satanism versus atheism is explored. This movie is far from only violence, it has heart.

28 Years Later - "Bone Temple"
What beliefs do we cling to when the world around us falls apart? It's a question we could be asking ourselves about our current state of the world and is the central question of this incarnation of the "28 - Later" franchise.
I thought 28 Years Later: Bone Temple was a solid entry overall and an enjoyable watch. The atmosphere and pacing worked well, and it kept me engaged throughout.

First of all... Nia DeCosta, all is forgiven. Your Candyman remake might stink, but The Bone Temple is proof that you can direct, and then some. The film looks stunning, it's well paced, superbly acted and delivers some bold choices that really pay off.

Fully expect to be down-voted purely due to the middling score for a film that appears to sharply divide beween those who find it the best in the 28 series and those who continue to hate the direction it has take with the latest sequels. I just don't find myself in either camp.
This is a cool sequel and it was unexpected. I understand that some zombie traditionalists might not like the direction but I enjoyed it.
Just read that I'm a bot. Well, I must be, this is a positive review!

Just got out of seeing this one on a giant ex IMAX screen and to me it's the best since 28 Days Later. Spesh when you compare it to the pale last outing. Everyone is great but demonic cult leader Sir Jimmy Crystal and old Doc Kelson are standouts. You even get a naked giant infected and Iron Maiden. Who could ask for more. Roll on the third.
28 years later:The Bone Temple (2025) - Atmosphere Over Answers**

A surprise at the beginning of the year. The fourth installment of the 28 series picks up a few days after the events of the third and delivers brutality and excellent acting. It follows Spike as he joins the cult group where everyone is named Jimmy, despite having no choice. We also learn more about Ralph Fiennes' character, Dr. Kelson, and how he and Samson are trying to find a cure for the virus. Later in the film, Spike's group and Dr. Kelson's group meet, and all I can say is: Iron Maiden. I won't say any more. The film is really good; I highly recommend it.

First of all, I have to say that I'm a fan of the 28 Days Later movie series and I'm a massive fan of the 2025 movie (28 Years Later). When I first watched the official trailer of the sequel, I liked it and I had high expectations about it, since I enjoyed the previous movie so much. Eventually, I went to the movies to watch it and I have to say that I'm kinda disappointed. I'm not saying that it was an awful movie, it's just that I had higher expectations about this one. When I first read the movie synopsis, I thought it was gonna be very interesting and kinda mysterious. Regarding the storyline, I have to say that it wasn't as well-written as I would like, it wasn't well-explained and it didn't felt like a zombie horror movie. Actually, the entire vibe of this movie was the exact opposite of the previous movie and I'm not saying that as a good thing. I mean, it wasn't as scary as the previous movie was, it wasn't as intense as the previous movie was and as I've said before, it didn't felt like a zombie horror movie. Just imagine that the screentime of the zombies was about 20 minutes, I'm not kidding. I have to admit, the gore level was the same as before, but there weren't as many kills as the 2025 movie had. Also, regarding the scariness, I have to say that it was kinda scary and there were some jumpscares, but it wasn't as insane and as shocking as the previous movie was. Moreover, I have to confess that I didn't enjoy the cinematography of the movie and I think the soundtrack/score didn't match the vibe of the movie. Anyway, I really hope the 3rd movie will be better than this one and it will have a similar vibe to 28 Years Later. Overall, "28 Years Later: The Bone Temple" was an average movie that I'm not sure if I would consider it a zombie horror movie because of the lack of zombies, furthermore the vibe of this movie was completely different than the previous movies. In conclusion, I'm not saying that it was a terrible movie and I would probably recommend it to my friends, it's just that it wasn't exactly what I was hoping for.

Riding straight off the coattails of it's impressive yet somewhat polarizing siblings, Bone Temple is a bolder, bloodier, and brainier sequel that lets the zombie aspect take a backseat in favor of a psychological and moral approach. Everything that seemed jarring and unexplained about 28 Years Later is more than made up for in this powder keg of a movie. It's the 28 Days Later franchise by way of "Lord of the Flies" and "A Clockwork Orange."

I need to start this review by saying that the Ralph Fiennes was perfect in this film. Fiennes expands graciously from his character introduced in the first film. Fiennes elevated every scene he was in, he brought a wide range of emotions from serious doctor to goofy dancing. The storyline with him and Sampson is beautiful done, I only wish the rest of the movie was like this.

You wont Regret this! This was an All Horror movie experience with a hint of Dark Comedy and then more Horror! Script was Perfect! Director kept scenes moving and the pacing was AMAZING, Esp. The last 30mins! This Movie is something i wouldve waited 28 Years for...But then which i want MOAR! Everyone had a fun Experience.

If it wasn't for Amanda playing Nina, this film would have been a lot worse. It was enjoyable but nothing in comparison to the book. I found Sydney sweeneys acting very wooden. Glad I watched it as I am a huge frieda McFadden fan, but I just found the lead role was lacking, and I did not warm to her like in the books.
Hate to be cliche and be another one who says "the book is better than the movie!!" But that truly is the case here.

The Housemaid is ridiculously fun, so contrived but ever so entertaining. This in part is helped by the go for broke acting of the leads, especially Seyfried. From the get go it is obvious who the real villain of the story is, but it is the why that keeps the intrigue intact until the reveal. This is a very much throwaway popcorn movie that delivers the goods. In the olden days it would be just the actresses giving the T & A, but now the guys get to show a bit of flesh too ... lol. This isn't any prestige movie, but it provides a fun and entertaining time at the movies.
6.9/10 (7) (Definitely Recommend)

The film starts in a familiar territory, but gradually proves to be more engaging than expected. At first, I assumed It would be the typical film about a familiar psychological drama, but it goes much further than that. Although the first half of the movie does not bring many new elements, it manages to keep you engaged and makes you pay attention to certain details. From that point on, there are some very effective plot twists.
As a huge fan of the book, the movie didn't disappoint me at all! The character portrayals were spot on. Especially Seyfrieds performance as Nina, hand her that Oscar already!!!

I don't understand why this is being underplayed. This movie was very very good. Acting, cinematography, direction, production...it was all superb. Amanda seyfried acted ridiculously well to me. Sidney Sweeney had an amazing role. The pace and development of the characters was great. Felt gripped the whole time. Bravo!

I listened to the audiobook summer of 2023 and was introduced to Freida McFadden. This movie follows the book extremely well and even though I couldn't remember every detail from the book, I recalled the main events. It's a decent movie and I appreciate its similarity to the book (probably because McFadden was an executive producer on this). Worth the watch!

I went into this with out reading the book, which I heard was excellent. Sadly found it predictable and poorly acted. Sydney Sweeney is lovely to look at but her acting here is dry and about as interesting as cardboard. The male character is Noxious but easy on the eyes, again,...bland and boring! The other female character is pretty good,-but jeez!-this movie is sadly overrated. The story was decent but the casting and direction was seriously lacking. Long shots of nothing, to try to add suspense, came across as self indulgent. Was really hoping for a good movie, but sadly predictable. Would have made a better movie of the week on TRU. Again, yeah.yawn.

This film is good, entertaining, solid, and cheesy fun, with just enough serious and surprisingly complex storylines to appeal to both mainstream audiences and lighter film critics. It builds steadily toward a crescendo--perhaps more than one-with a handful of well-timed twists and turns that should satisfy popcorn-loving moviegoers from college age to adulthood.

I realize things have to build but it was pretty lackluster until the twist. I did listen to the audiobook and figured out a main component of the twist very early on so that detracts from my enjoyment. I never find nudity necessary in a movie and it is always thrown in for purely prurient reasons and cheapens a movie. If you want a sex movie go watch one it is not needed in regular movies to show that sex occurred.

While I like thriller movies, this movie just didn't have the wow factor for me. The movie started well, but the middle of the movie kinda dragged. The problem I found with this movie compared to other great murder thrillers I've watched is it didn't send shivers down my neck. Watching it sometimes felt more like a love drama movie than thriller. The violent ending I thought happened too quickly, but as the movie is based of a book maybe there are limitations.

Millie (Sydney Sweeney) is hired by Nina Winchester (Amanda Seyfried) a rich social lite to is hired to be a housemaid, much of the surprise by her husband Andrew (Brandon Sklenar), but Millie will discover that in their household, nothing is quite what it seems.

Though the first act feels rushed and a bit far-fetched, it pays off with a twist I didn't see coming. The intimacy is tasteful, both leads shine, and it's great to see Amanda Seyfried commanding a role she absolutely nails. I was engaged the entire film and the ending made me linger. Well-Done to the crew and cast.

The Housemaid (2025) is a psychological thriller movie based on the 2022 novel of the same name directed by Paul Feig and it follows a struggling woman staring work as a housemaid for an affluent, elite couple. This is a movie that caught my eye because of Paul Feig and the cast, so I waited for it to come out and the movie was awesome.

Millie Calloway, played by Sydney Sweeney, lives in her car when she gets the chance to work as a housemaid for a wealthy family. Nina Winchester, Amanda Seyfried, her husband Andrew, Brandon Sklenar and their daughter Cece seem picture perfect at first. Millie even gets her own room in the attic. By the second day on the job, it becomes clear that nothing is what it seemed.

Aside from actors and actresses doing their best, I cannot say that the plot follows. This movie was so utterly dumb that it makes me question today's cinema. The plot that could grow into something meaningful is being destroyed by empty and shallow dialogues, and what's worse it is literally a suspense for people who scroll on their phones. It is dumb.
Granted it's good, and I like most of PTA's films, but it's not like this is anywhere near as brilliant as something like There Will Be Blood or The Master.

The film kept my attention and I genuinely enjoyed watching it, but I walked away feeling like something was missing. I'm still not sure why critics are so ecstatic about it - it's a solid piece of work, just not exceptional in the way the reviews suggest. I don't regret the time spent, yet I don't feel any desire to rewatch it either.
Went to see the movie because of the cast, but the promise, the delivery, and the highly confusing message was disappointing. No coherence anything at all, ended up walking out before the end.

I saw 'One Battle After Another' last night, and I'm still not sure I get the hype. On paper, the film has everything: social commentary, action, radical politics, immigration, parenthood, even extremism. It tries to juggle so many weighty ideas at once - and I do applaud that - it's ambitious, topical, clearly trying to stir the pot. But ambition alone doesn't make for satisfying cinema, and this one ends up messy.

I didn't care for the opening scenes but after 20 or 30 minutes I thought it got significantly better. Not a great opening, very uneven compared to the rest. The film as a whole gets a lot better the longer you stick with it. The acting is the main reason my score is so high. Leo is great in this and so is Sean Penn. With all the nominations for benicio I thought he was gonna have a bigger performance but he's relegated to a significant side character. The action is good and the cinematography looks great. The dialogue is interesting. I just don't think its as great as everybody says it is. I had a good time for the most part. Its a little long but after that beginning the pace moves a lot smoother. There's not much explanation. Like we are told all of these things but are not told why to think this way or given reasons why we should think said way. Its a straight forward plot and I see why people like it so much. I think its a movie for the times and that's the reasons for the high scores but in the future years from now I don't think it will age as well as other films being released currently. I just think its a really good film I don't understand the glowing reviews calling it a masterpiece or winning a significant number of awards compared to other current greats. The character development is pretty thin. We are told these people are this and these people are that..not exactly sure what the message is supposed to be at the end of the day. Are they good guys? Are they bad guys? Morally grey? Its basically a story about a group of people trying to start a revolution. I like the story but don't try to think about it too much as you watch it just consume. Its heavily political so you'll likely love this or hate it. I'm leaning towards really liking it a lot I just think its overrated.

The title of my review is automatically going to be downvoted but it just represents exactly how I feel. This was a perfectly serviceable film that I was able to watch from start to finish and come out saying "yeah it was fine."

What is this movie about? It starts with the "French 75", a group with ideolical goals. Their rebellion changes nothing and their members soon end up in jail. This is portrayed without obvious moral underlining. The other half of the Paul Thomas Anderson movie is a family drama. That's also when the video editor decided to continue his work on an old VCR device. We get to see intense emotions, wild car chases and a few comedic performances.

Paul Thomas Anderson's One Battle After Another is a film that wants to be epic but ends up didactic. There's no denying its technical accomplishments: the cinematography is vivid, almost painterly at times, and Leonardo DiCaprio and Sean Penn deliver performances that are magnetic, commanding your attention even when the story falters.

A little rough start which might alienate some, but really worth the stay. My favorite in quite awhile, with Leonardo and Sean Penn at their best. The dark humor throughout is perfect, and the knowing there might be a group like the Christmas Society is truly frightening. This one will sweep in the awards season.

Today I watched *one battle after another*. I had read all the glowing reviews beforehand, and I knew it was being praised as one of the best films of the year... but if I can give you one piece of advice: if you're going to see it, go in with no expectations-and avoid reading other people's opinions first.

It seems people must be overly easily impressed giving this 9 or 10. Dont understand the hype. Its messy and just not that engaging. Its well made but its like a dish that smells and looks fantastic but tastes a bit bland. Difficult to say which ingredients are missing, but one thing that struck me from early on is I didnt really like or care about any of the characters. Many of them are just nasty, unlikeable. It couldnt seem.to make its mind up what it wanted to be, and many long scenes were pointless. The action wasnt anywhere near as insane as people say. The chase was good, but Bullett still has the best car chase of all time! It was a mixed bag. Often silly comedic at odd times, which wasnt very funny either. I felt like it has four or five writers all pulling it in different directions of action, thriller, dark humour, and not that great at any of it. It held me, but only just, and it does pick up after about an hour. I think if Id been on my own (my partner had the same review as me after) I may have walked, which I very rarely do
I kept thinking it was like a try hard Rob Zombie/Tarantino/Scorcese movie but fell way short. I gave it 5, but its maybe a 6.5 at best.

The movie "One Battle After Another", in summary, is about a former revolutionary on a mission to save his missing daughter. Directed and co-written by Paul Thomas Anderson, it's a thrilling political action flick that really shows off, once again, his talent for both writing and directing. However, the movie isn't consistent in its construction; at times it's unconvincing, and other times it feels unfocused. More than once, I had the same reaction I did with last year's "Emilia Pérez": a wildly original story that often seems to jump around without much logic, where anything can happen.

One Battle After Another is a fun movie that stars Leonardo DiCaprio. DiCaprio does an amazing job in his role as Bob. The cinematography and plot were pretty strong. Moderate comedic moments will give you a laugh. This is an entertaining movie to watch, it's just really long. I liked the whole plot of Bob running away from the police. A fun movie worthy of an 8/10.

'One Battle After Another' hits the current zeitgeist with a story that feels incredibly relevant and urgent. The acting is absolutely top-tier: Leonardo DiCaprio delivers a fantastic performance, yet somehow, Sean Penn manages to outshine him, delivering one of the best roles of his career.

This film is markedly overrated and does not merit a flawless 10/10 rating. While DiCaprio delivers a compelling and nuanced performance that elevates the production, the same cannot be said for his co-lead.

I really didn't expect to write a review, but the amount of PTA bots calling this movie a masterpiece made me say two or three things. I think it's a perfectly solid movie, it looks good, the pace is okay, the actors are perfectly talented but not used to their full potential. The script is what lowers the quality and impression of this movie because the jokes are cringe or better said cheap and predictable. But okay jokes aside, what's missing the most is a deeper dive into the characters and their relationships, who they are and why they do the things they do, but everything remains kind of surface level, unfinished, which results in me simply not caring about these characters. The action is nowhere near as crazy as they want you to think and the music, although great, is a bit too distracting at times. I'll conclude this review because I have nothing to say except that it's a perfectly solid movie but pls don't expect a masterpiece just because a big director's name is attached to it.

I honestly had fun watching this. It's not perfect and it's not trying to be some big epic, but it keeps moving and never really gets boring. Every time one conflict ends, another one starts, so there's always something happening.
Alright, I went to see it. I just got back. Long story short: I'm a little disappointed, honestly.

People are calling this film Anderson's masterpiece. I can't agree. It's watchable and even good, but it would benefit from some serious editing as the last half really begins to drag. Pro Tip: The big chase scene in a feature film shouldn't drag! Over-the-top characters are so plentiful that it's almost a relief when one isn't (I would have loved to have seen more of Benicio Del Toro's sensei!). I'm not sure how this can be called PTA's masterpiece when it really doesn't stand up to films like There Will Be Blood, Phantom Thread, and Magnolia). Those films, too, have plenty of over-the-top characters, but their stories are just more compelling.

Good acting from the leads, great performances but the spark from the novel was missing. As a fan of the book, the story was way too condensed and way too many plot points were altered or completely removed. This would've benefited from being a limited series thru Max in the vein of White Lotus with each episode being a different past vacation then flashing to the current timeline.

People We Meet on Vacation is a quietly confident romantic drama that understands its characters before it ever tries to impress its audience. Directed by Brett Haley, the film leans into emotional honesty and patient storytelling, allowing the relationship at its center to unfold in a way that feels natural, believable, and earned.

I thoroughly enjoyed this one. It was original & funny. I've lowered my expectations over the years regarding these straight to streaming movies, but this one definitely exceeded them. The two leads are likable & have good chemistry. Watching how they meet & then continue their friendship over their once a year vacations was really fun. It's clear at the beginning of the movie that their friendship is strained. I enjoyed watching how things progressed over the years & what led to where we find them in the beginning. The scenery was beautiful & their relationship was very believable. Overall a good movie that I would definitely watch again.
I've read the book and the book has so much depth which is expected but I would've preferred this book to be adapted into a series with each episode featuring a different summer.

It's been ages since the Rom-Com genre in Hollywood has seen a naturally effortlessly expressive actress like Emily since Meg Ryan or Kate Hudson. There r some amazing ones outside of Hollywood, but unfortunately haven't made their journey to this side yet. So, Emily Bader has been a breath of fresh air. I was already a fan from My Lady Jane. Now I'm a full air conditioner!!! Hollywood, please stop forcing Melbourne Melanie on audience and put Emily in all the Rom-Com !!!

It was a Saturday night, my wife and I had just finished our weekly steak and red wine dinner, with chocolate cake of course, and needed a movie to watch to seal the evening. We found this one, streaming on NFLX.

I have watched countless rom-coms, but I hesitate to call this a typical rom-com because it is not cookie-cutter. It is original and unique, perhaps the best I've seen in 10 years. The story and performances are top-notch. While all the actors nailed it, Tom Blyth stole the show. The movie is funny, it is romantic, it is heartwarming. You won't regret watching this, even if you are not into romantic movies.

A classic rom-com if there ever was one. I laughed out loud several times at Poppy's antics and found Alex's fond exasperation to be adorable. My only gripe is that it was pretty predictable and a little undercooked in the last twenty minutes--everything felt very rushed and a little forced. But overall I enjoyed it!

I read the book and I like it. Although the movie is a little different, I think it maintained the essence of the story. I felt the same emotions with both formats. I really enjoyed Poppy and Alex's romance, their crazy vacation, and also their personalities and tastes. I feel that the film didn't show that side of them enough; Alex wasn't portrayed as the same reader and passionate lover of literature and teaching as he is in the book. As for Poppy, there was nothing more to add. Overall, I really enjoyed it and I definitely recommend reading the book as well.

This would've eaten as a netflix limited series. Way too many time jumps but not enough slow burn. Two hours is not enough for this story
the idea was so romantic, but the execution was a little rushed. That final speech hit me emotionally and i don't even fully know why. I felt the intention more than the impact, but it's comforting in a very netflix-coded way

Loved the light-hearted romantic movie #ThePeopleWeMeetOnVacation that has a bit of a twist in the theme where the opposites that meet oddly have a great time together and even though the LM already has a girlfriend, they agree to meet every summer for a vacation together. The platonic vacations always have flirtatious overtones but they never cross the line. Naturally, there comes a point when the decision friends or lovers or never see each other again comes into play. I enjoyed it and thought the LM does a great job playing the role of the preppy good looking career and stable wannabe.

I read this book when it first came out and have loved Alex and Poppy since. While the movie had different beats than the book, it did it justice and the characters truly came through. Tom and Emily embodied the Alex and Poppy I pictured, and this is the kind of adaptation you want for such a fun and loving summer love story.

I'll happily sit through a bad romcom, but this one was genuinely painful. While the leads had some chemistry, the film itself was utterly empty. There was no emotional weight, no character development, and no real invitation for the audience to connect with anyone on screen. The book is supposed to be great, so I'm wondering how a story with so much potential managed to feel so empty.

5 stars for the romantic leads. Though I'm not sure the title accurately describes what I just watched. For such a verbose title I'd at least expect to meet some new strange vacationers. Fair enough though, and glad it was free. What a thirst trap. Seriously though, the actors did an amazing job with a mid-level script.

Put this on as I was scrolling through Netflix and pleasantly surprised, it was a rom com that was actually romantic and actually funny without being cringey or overly stupid. The leads were cast well and the writing was solid, it was nice to see their journey from strangers to best friends. So give it a watch!
It reminded me a lot of "One Day." I'm happy to say that this film has a lot going for it. The lead actors are perfectly cast. They are terrific in their roles.

If One Day and When Harry Met Sally had a baby then it might look a little like People We Meet On Vacation. It's not that the kid is ugly, indeed it's quite attractive, however it will always draw comparisons to one of its parents and pales by comparison.

This was such an amazing movie!! It ment so much to me for some reason. The message behind the story is really sweet. This was such a pretty movie to just look at the color and lighting really really was phenomenal. I genuinely have no notes for this movie. The acting was so good and the chemistry was off the charts. The plot was also really good I have not read the book that it is based off of but even as just a movie is was a masterpiece. The time jumps were so well done and it was just really good!!

The book is so much better (unsurprisingly). The movie lacked a lot of the context and character development necessary to effectively pull off the "friends to lovers" trope. It felt forced to be honest and there were so many scenes where I was left wanting more dialogue and instead got an awkward one-liner or just a kiss. I feel like they could have done a way better job telling this story...

I love friends-to-lovers tropes, but not this one. Poppy character is so annoying and selfish that it's simply impossible to watch. People rarely change. After a while, she will start to feel bored and blame him for everything. Relationships like this usually last a few years and then end in a messy divorce, leaving miserable children behind.
The Good

Normally I'm not really into this kind of movie, but the story completely pulled me in and kept me glued to the screen from start to finish. The acting was very good, the performances are strong, and the shots are genuinely beautiful
and i kinda love the plot in the end.

Poppy (Emily Bader) is an extrovert. Alex (Tom Blyth) is an introvert. They meet in college and end up going on vacation together for almost a decade. They call themselves best friends. For nearly two hours, the movie shows them circling each other until, shockingly, they end up together in the end.

The movie is fairly decent, and I appreciated the fact that it isn't a standard, predictable film. It has a few genuinely good moments and some interesting ideas. However, despite these positives, I couldn't finish it. Large portions of the movie felt boring, and over time it became predictable even within its own storyline. Eventually, it stopped being enjoyable to watch. Overall, I wouldn't recommend it.
What a surprise of a movie this is. It almost feels like it came out of nowhere and took over the world. Is it really that good? Here are the positives and negatives of Marty Supreme:
I saw this at the Curzon,Colchester with both Nigel and Deirde.

I came into this not knowing much other than I'm not a huge Chalemet fan. I loved it. It was totally manic and I couldn't keep my eyes off it. Yes, he is a horrible person and while I wasn't exactly rooting for him I also found I didn't want him to fail. I have to attribute that to the acting. I had 2 literal gasp out loud moments which I always love in a theater. My companions didn't love it as much as I did. They both criticized a lack of plot. I guess I see that but I just enjoyed the ride.

Josh Saffdie continues his excellent run of movies by maintaining his trademark suffocating atmosphere in which a series of interwoven plotlines build into a never ending anxiety attack. Chalamet is a tour de force as Marty, playing his narcissism perfectly where you end up routing for him despite making bad and self centered decisions at all every turn. The anachronistic 80s synth pop/rock soundtrack is sensational and the film lets you know it's willing to get weird from the outset with two standout scenes (sperm and honey).

The Safdie split has proven Benny Safdie is an underrated acting talent, but it may have been Josh Safdie's direction that bottled electricity in the brothers' previous films. As "Marty Supreme" has the same chaotic, kinetic energy as "Uncut Gems" with a more expansive setting and more layered themes.

Marty Supreme is a fantastic piece of filmmaking by director Josh Safdie. He is a filmmaker I've long admired for the projects he made with his brother, especially Uncut Gems and Good Time. This marks the first film I've seen that he has directed on his own, and he absolutely knocked it out of the park. Safdie's confident direction and sharp/quick storytelling abilities are on full display here. Here's why I loved this movie so much and why I believe it stands as one of the very best films of 2025

I had high expectations for this film. The trailer was amazing, and it's what drew me in and set the bar high. But man, oh man, how they've exceeded my already high expectations. Never has a film ever done so.

It's the same beat over and over pounded onto the screen. Chalamet is amazing as always, but this character is so unlikable and mean spirited. I didn't find it enjoyable to watch someone walk all over other people for his own gain. The final scenes felt contrived and seemed to ask the audience to forgive too much.

This film made me remember why i loved movies so much in the first place. Watching it at the theatre with an amazing audience gave me a ton of inspiration and energy for the new year. Timothee Chalamet embodied the role of Marty McFly flawlessly and I throuoghly enjoyed the ride with the awesome characters. Thumbs up from me.

The plot was convoluted. So many disconnected subplots going on. Not a single likeable character. Supporting characters that seemed forced into the overall story. Some decent performances, surprisingly the best was from the guy from Shark Tank. It had no real direction, which makes you wonder if all the connections were left on the cutting room floor to make time. Can't see how this is getting awards buzz. Watch if you have nothing better, but don't go out of your way to see it.

Timmy is wonderful as always. But Marty is terrible, which made it very difficult for me to get excited about him. I paused the film several times because it was too much effort to follow Marty and the plot. Maybe I'm too ignorant for this masterpiece, but about halfway through, I decided not to watch any further. This happens to me quite often with Oscar-worthy films... somehow they don't really move me. It's a shame.

Timothée Chalamet once again proves why he's one of the greatest actors of his generation. The range of emotions he displays in this film is absolutely brilliant-the fire in his eyes feels real, raw, and captivating. His chemistry with his costar gwyneth adding an extra layer of depth to the film.

Marty Supreme is a pure chaos film starring Timothée Chalamet, with a relentless pace that never lets the audience breathe for even a second. It feels like a movie that perfectly embodies Josh Safdie's signature style-especially in its final act, which plays out at a constant heart rate of 200 BPM. But whether it's for you or not... that depends.
Last year he played Bob Dylan. Now he's playing champion-level ping-pong.
Marty Supreme is a fast-paced, immersive experience that had me on the edge of my seat for every second of its runtime.

Josh Safdie delivers an incredibly fast-paced energized story about a man who in a post-war new york has a dream to be the best in the world. Fans of Good Time will love this project as Chamalet's electric performance as Marty Mauser has him running around the city desperately trying to find his way to his destiny. This movie had me on the edge of my seat, and the table tennis matches were incredibly choreographed. This is the film of the year for me, I can't wait to rewatch.
Don't believe the dummies on this site. Some people just don't know ball.
This could have been a brilliant 98 minute movie.

Personally, this type of genre is something I'd easily pick out but on a random Thursday, why not? And I went in to watch without any expectations-and I really enjoyed it. I love how I couldn't predict anything that would happen next, and that's what I miss most whenever I watch films especially from this generation.

While the performances are certainly good, and the frenetic and energetic cinematography and spirit of the film are nice, the story itself feels lacking. A young man pursues his dream of becoming a table-tennis champion, and along the way there are challenges. That's pretty much it. Nothing groundbreaking. It's basically a common sports film we've all seen for the umpteenth time made to soothe the masses. Throughout the runtime, I remember thinking that it's both too long and contains things that work. Quite a few times I wondered when the film would conclude.
Marry Supreme desperately wants to feel important, but instead it feels exhausting.

William and Agnes Shakespeare are devastated by the loss of their child, Hamnet, through plague. Life, however, offers no pause for grief; Agnes still has other children to care for, and William must continue working. Their relationship begins to buckle under the strain, each processing loss in very different ways.
I read Maggie O'Farrell's novel Hamnet and admired it a great deal. Then I saw the film, directed by Chloé Zhao, and I have to say: I liked the movie even more.
Hamnet is the kind of film you should only watch if you're ready to cry. I went in knowing very little, not realizing it would stay with me longer than almost anything else I've seen.

Hamnet is my favorite movie of the year. What a beautiful script. This movie is a tearjerker. It's the most emotional I've been watching a movie in years. The performances from Jessie Buckley and Paul Mescal are some of the best performances this decade. It also includes some of the best child acting I've ever seen. A film about love and loss that hits all the right notes perfectly. It even manages to have some really funny moments as well. The cinematography is beautiful, the editing is smooth, and the score is phenomenal. Chloe Zhao knocked it out of the park directing. It's definitely her best movie. No notes. 10/10.
Watched at the 2025 Toronto International Film Festival.
What do You see?

The performances across the board here are really great. Buckley, Mescal, and J. Jupe are the standouts. The cinematography of the pastoral is sublime. You feel the wind blowing through the trees, the rustling of the leaves. The premise is moving, and the use of the arts as a way to work through grief and trauma, as displayed in the film, was poignant.
For the second time this year, I sat down in the theater convinced that I was going to be emotionally devastated by a film everyone was talking about, and I ended up feeling....not much at all.

Fictional stories about the life of William Shakespeare have been created for many decades, if not centuries. None other than George Bernard Shaw wrote a short play called "The Dark Lady of the Sonnets." I remember seeing William Gibson's play, A CRY OF PLAYERS, in the late 1960s with Anne Bancroft and Frank Langella as "Will" and "Anne." I read Anthony Burgess's novel, NOTHING LIKE THE SUN, about Shakespeare's alleged affair with the "dark lady of the sonnets" (who was an African in his version) a couple of years later. At the end of the 20th Century came Robert Nye's novel, THE LATE MR. SHAKESPEARE, about a homosexual actor in Shakespeare's troupe who played women's roles. In 1998 came Tom Stoppard's clever screenplay for the Oscar-winning film, SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE. I'm sure that there have been many others. The latest entry into the field is HAMNET, a best-selling novel (I have not read it) about the death of Shakespeare's young son, which has now been made into a movie. It is the weakest of the bunch.

Here I thought a "hamnet" was some kind of trap for pigs. Boy was I wrong! HAMNET is actually the new movie directed by Academy Award winner Chloé Zhao. It is adapted from the 2020 historical fiction of the same name written by Maggie O'Farell, who cowrote the film with Zhao. It tells a story of William Shakespeare (Paul Mescal) and what could have been his inspiration to create one of the most popular plays in the history of the Globe, Hamlet. He quickly falls in love with Agnes (Jessie Buckley), who like Will, sees things differently. As Will sees things through his words on the page, Agnes sees things through nature, both of them outcasts of society. When tragedy strikes their family, both deal with their grief in different ways. This movie has moments that are hard to watch, but it's only because the acting doesn't feel like a performance. Utilizing close-up shots, it feels like I was in the room. Not only is Buckley going to get an award, I believe 12-year-old Jacobi Jupe as the titular character deserves something. It's a very clever bit of casting having his older brother Noah Jupe in this as well. There were a couple of shots that left me breathless. I don't want to say too much more about this, but I will say that art can be an opportunity for healing, and the movie has a way of depicting the spiritual power of art as a means of processing trauma. It also has an amazing score, using a rendition of the song On the Nature of Daylight. There are a few critics that have said this movie just never clicked for them emotionally. I've tried wrapping my head around that, to no avail. Overall, HAMNET is an extremely beautiful tragedy, an emotional masterpiece that might not click with you. Remember, keep your heart open, and bring tissues.

What a beautiful movie from Chloé Zhao. The film follows the life of a regular family in a past era, focusing on their relationships and how they deal with life's challenges. It's about love, loss, and family bonds, but it doesn't hit you over the head with drama. Things unfold slowly and quietly - small gestures, looks, and silences speak just as much as words. The English countryside almost feels alive, quietly watching over the family, and the story shows that human emotions - grief, care, hope - are timeless, even across centuries.

Paul Mescal gives a breathtaking performance in Hamnet. His acting is powerful, emotional, and so natural that every moment feels real. The film itself is beautifully directed, visually stunning, and full of heart. It's a deeply moving story that stays with you long after watching. A masterpiece - one of the best films of the year!

After winning Oscars for Frances McDormand and herself by portraying contemporary America as "Nomadland," director Chloé Zhao goes back 400 years to Elizabethan England to create her next masterpiece.
The entire movie is beautiful, perfect and authentic. The ending is a combination of beauty and devastating emotion the likes of which I've never felt before. The movie must be seen for this alone.

I don't think I've ever said this about a movie before, but I wish Hamnet had been told in non-chronological order. Or I wish it had done something a little unexpected. If you know the premise here, and have seen a Chloe Zhao movie before, and have seen a handful of Jesse Buckley and Paul Mescal performances before, close your eyes for two hours, and picture what Hamnet will look and sound like, and imagine the most generic structure and sequence of events you can for a period drama about love, family, and grief, and you will likely picture something close to what Hamnet is. You could watch this movie in your head, almost, without having seen the movie. There didn't need to be surprises here, necessarily, but I don't know. I just had this feeling like I've seen this film before, even if I haven't. I got quite bored by the time the final 40-ish minutes came around, and I was somewhat frustrated by how safe it plays things.

A viewer's reaction to this film will likely depend heavily on what they're hoping to get from it. If strong acting capable of evoking powerful emotion is enough, this is a very good film. If, however, you're looking for a story built around richly developed characters, it comes up short.

A fascinating story becomes a so-so movie. What's off? A lot. Mescal's Shakespeare doesn't suggest a man with a great interest in the theater or writing. In fact he's rather dull. We are told things about life in Stratford but don't always see them. The direction is uneven. It seems to lose focus at times. What am I supposed to be noticing here. Scenes containing two live birth go on and on. Some scenes sag. The print I saw in a theater was not very sharp. Why does Ann (Agnes) laugh at the end. The writing gets very pedestrian at times. Some scenes plod along. Tighter editing would have helped. Also tighter continuity. The premise here to explain Hamlet is potentially intriguing but this telling doesn't do it justice. It's not terrible but it's not very good either.
This movie is about remembrance, dedication, love.

Hamnet is a great drama dealing with an unimaginable tragedy that's designed to peak at the very end thanks to an impactful finale which shows how art can be used as a way to heal pain and acts as a testament to the emotional power of cinema through the transcendent power of theatre. The film recontextualises a classic play into something deeply personal and it has wonderful pacing because it knows exactly when is the right time to move between each act.

If you've seen the first two installments, the third is unlikely to surprise you. What we get once again is flawless, mesmerizing visuals stretched across nearly three hours of screen time, accompanied by familiar characters, predictable dramaturgy, and a storyline reduced to almost primitive straightforwardness.

Like many others, I have also been irritated by James Cameron's often blunt dialogue: "unobtanium," the persistent "bro" and "cuz," and other remnants of a flattened Earth vernacular. In 'Fire and Ash', we are even treated to a "high four," suggesting that Jake Sully has managed to export some of the most annoying aspects of human culture to Pandora. On the plus side, Sigourney Weaver got to say a variation of a line of hers from 'Aliens', which was a nice little Easter egg.

I had a good time with this, but make no mistake: this is just the same movie as the sequel with some slight variation. Again, we have Quaritch as the bad guy playing cat and mouse with Jake. Again, we spend a majority of the movie following a subplot about harvesting a precious liquid from whales (or whatever you call them), which seems like it's tacked on to bring the movie to the 3 hour runtime for no good reason (an Avatar tradition at this point). Again, the finale involves the same characters battling it out in the same circumstances with a frustrating lack of resolution. The first two acts introduced some more darkness and stronger emotional beats than either of the first two movies, and the addition of the Ash people was an interesting take to finally see the bad side of Navi. But the third act just phones it in and goes for the familiar route.

The Way of Water: Part Two Would've been a much more appropriate title because that's exactly what this movie was. More of the same movie that we got with TWoW...
Pros: Entertaining, action packed, stunning visuals, ultimately fun overall, and fun to live inside of the world of Avatar.

Some time ago in the previous century, James Cameron first developed the idea for the Avatar films. When he realized that the tools available at the time weren't sufficient to fully realize his vision, he refused to compromise and made a decision: to put the project completely on ice until technology caught up with what he had imagined. Over the following years, he focused primarily on technological research, working on innovative filming systems and motion-capture methodologies.

16 years ago, I was visually impressed by James Cameron's Avatar and it was my first 3D movie in the theatre. The movie also had a very old school kind of emotional drama in it. 3 years ago when I watched Avatar: Way of Water, I was stunned by the amazing visuals in IMAX 3D. Hands down, it was my best IMAX 3D experience. But, I walked out of the theatre with an incomplete feeling because of the unconvincing story and screenplay. I was thinking maybe the third part is going to show us something very new and blow our minds again. After watching Avatar: Fire and Ash my expectations were crushed and how.

Visually stunning from start to finish, with some of the strongest character moments in the series so far. While Avatar 3 doesn't quite land its central theme as clearly or cohesively as Avatar 2, I ended up enjoying it more overall thanks to how engaging the characters are. Their relationships, conflicts, and quieter moments carried a lot of emotional weight and kept me invested throughout. Avatar 2 is probably the better "complete package" in terms of structure and thematic focus, but Avatar 3 won me over by leaning harder into character, which made the experience feel more personal and memorable.

Unfortunately, Avatar Fire and Ash lacked what made Avatar (2009) a must see film. Emotional depth and a deep connection to the characters is why we fell in love with Avatar. In Fire and Ash, character motivations seem to be scattered all over the place. The story concentrates primarily around Spider, and his desire to fit in with the rest of the Na'vi. This narrative often times felt weak and struggled to drive the film forward, hitting a wall and slowly disengaging us from the film. I thought James Cameron directed fairly well, giving us great action scenes, while the visuals and sound were also a positive. Ultimately, this film fell short of expectations and leaves you with a mixture of disappointment and frustration.

So I've watched all the movies, and I simply don't understand what the repetitiveness is all about. This is the story! Humans invading another planet! Na'vi having to fight them! This is the main plot! I loved the first movie, loved the second movie more than the first and this one I simply thought it was incredible! It's not only the visuals, but the story too! I loved getting to know more clans, the fights, the places, the relationships. It has everything: emotion, comedy, tragedy, romance, darkness... What do you mean there is nothing new? I think it has plenty of new things and I think this is the best movie of the franchise yet. I truly hope we will get the rest of the movies.
And btw. The subtitle of the movie is misleading. There is just 5 Minutes Fire and Ash. The movie had to be called Way of the Water 2.

I've always had a soft spot for the first *Avatar*. When it came out, I was a kid, and it genuinely felt like something special. The world of Pandora was stunning, the creatures and environments felt alive, and the movie delivered a sense of scale and immersion that very few films had managed at the time. Even though many people criticized the story for borrowing familiar ideas, I never really minded. The execution was strong enough that it still felt fresh and memorable.
When the movie started I thought i was actually watching a trailer for a new Avatar game for Xbox or PS5, then i realised to my horror that it was the movie.

I actually really love this movie. I just watched it in the theatre and the whole movie i just couldn't get a minute to go to the toilet, because i was absolutely hooked to the story, probably because i also love the first 2 movies. The new tribe is very interesting and definitely something different, especially Varang, I love her. Go and watch the movie!!

This movie proves that the makers can push their limits in making a masterpiece, this movie concludes what it all started in THE WAY OF WATER, perfect action scenes, remarkable acting, great dialogues, the VFX, it's a beautiful creation, just enjoyed watching it. Do not miss to watch this one, Avatar movie fans must not miss, non avatar movie fans must watch the previous two movies in order to understand this one.

I am going to be honest. How can a franchise make 5 billion USD+ (more than the last 8 Marvel Movies combined) yet not making an impact in the film industry besides looking good? I doubt that Cameron has so many things to tell that he needs two more whole new movie for it, cause this movie is over 3 hours, yet it doesn't have any depth to it that would deserve this runtime. It's basically the same plot as Way of Water, no, scratch that, it's Avatar 2's plot that wasn't told in 2 but rather was told in 3 instead.

My sister asked me to come with her to watch the new Avatar. I thought the first two were pretty good, but had no desire to watch the 3rd one at the movie theater. I decided to go because I didn't want my sister to go alone.. and let me tell you! This is one of my top 5 movies of all time. I was engaged every single second. The story line was incredible. It was beyond worth every single second. This is supposed to be a 5 movie series, and it better be just that. If you're one the fence about watching this movie, WATCH IT! This is a must watch! I am not a huge movie lover, and I am in love with this movie.

This is what cinema was made for. Amazing CGI and an immersive world as always in this series, but also the story is surprisingly emotional, even if it clearly has some similaritys to "The way of water". For me it was defenitly stronger than the second and approximatly as good ad the first movie. Watch this movie in the best cinema you can, you can't get the full experience at home.

The third chapter of Avatar is stunning, just like the previous ones. Visually it's on another level, with some of the best CGI and world-building you'll see in a cinema. The soundtrack does a lot of heavy lifting too, in my opinion. So the cast does.

I just watched it, and i have alot of thoughrd mostly positive obviously by my rating
Positives: visuals, the new tribe, action, the sully family, colonel quaritch, set up for the next film(if we get it) , world building
Mixed:the Humour(theres not many comedy moments but some were funny others were not), some Plotlines felt underveloped, the main antagonist(the fire tribe leader)
Negatives:just like with every avatar movie to long (not as bad as the second one tho), the villains(human),the wind tribe lacking screen time and set up, feels like avatar way of water 2
Overall for a avatar movie i think its really good and despite the long run tine and the human villains being(plus the fact itd almost way of water 2) its still fun and enjoy able and i think it is better writen then the other avatar movies (not by alot btw)

So damn great at least to me visually stunning, improvement on Spider's character, new great villain by Oona Chaplin, and the superb entertainment most the time even though it's similar to 2nd one - Fire and Ash was magnificent! I think it's cool how Stephen Lang has been a villian since the early 90's. Wonder what's gonna happen with sequels regardless loved this one a lot.

Far from perfect and far too long, the flaws in James Cameron's third Avatar outing, Fire and Ash are there for all to see and in reality, far from surprising but as per his first two multi-billion dollar outings Cameron's latest visual feast is still a fun and entertaining blockbuster that deserves to put bums on cinema seats.
Jake and Neytiri once again find themselves fighting for their freedom and their world, only now a new threat lurks on the horizon.

Whose idea was it to turn Predator into a beat-for-beat Disney-style adventure film? This is Predator in name only. There is virtually none of the horror, tension, or atmosphere from the original. It feels like a cardboard cutout, generic kids movie. It may as well have been a Disney Channel original.

So after the Disneyfication of Star Wars and Alien, we finally get around to the abject ruination of the beloved Predator series. True, Shane Black came mighty close with The Predator back in 2018 and best not mention Alien v. Predator: Requiem at all but, in the excellent wake of Prey and Predator: Killer of Killers, hopes were extremely high for whatever Dan Trachtenberg would come up with next.
For an action adventure movie this was a solid experience. It was directed competently and the visuals were quite decent as well as the soundtrack. I liked the message of the movie as well.
Wth did I just watch?!

It's finally here, a Predator movie that doesn't take itself too seriously, yet remains incredibly well-made and thoroughly entertaining, Dan Trachtenberg, who already delivered the most serious and still the best Predator film to date with Prey, is clearly having a blast with Predator: Badlands, from the very first scene, the movie hooks you with one of the most exciting and promising intros in the franchise.

This movie was highly anticipated by me. I am a fan of not only the movie, but more importantly, the comics! Anyone who is only watching the movies, is missing the backstories and sequels to the movies. I won't make this a long winded review, you can scroll anywhere else and read those. This is more of a "why" to the direction of the movie.

YEESSSS!!! As a big fan of the original 1987 Schwarzenegger movie, I have seen all the Predator (and Alien) movies they have put out...including the ones that were awful and wasted my time (i.e. Requiem).

Hey. Visually all there. But remember when Star Wars started throwing in gags? I mean here we go again. More pandering and less epic. And for what? Contrived relationships and nerfed villains. And yes we get it: "copy right copy right trademarked" did anyone else catch that? C'mon guys, I just want to watch a movie.

The recent films have completely lost the suffocating horror and nerve-wracking tension that defined the first two entries. It feels like the writers no longer understand the true essence of the Yautja. In the original film, it wasn't just a mindless killer - it was a calculating hunter. Remember how it used its toxic dart to paralyze its prey before firing the plasma caster? Its weapon wasn't just for destruction; it could adjust its power and precision. That level of detail made the Yautja terrifying - a cold, silent, methodical predator who hunted one victim at a time, unseen, and only revealed itself when absolutely necessary or when its cloaking device was damaged.

Predator: Badlands is what happens when a studio strays so far from the sci-fi horror roots of the franchise that you can barely recognise the world you once loved. The tension, the grit, the primal fear that made the originals unforgettable, none of it survives here. Instead, we get glossy CGI fireworks, hollow lore dumps, and characters who wander through the story like they're immune to common sense. The Predator, once a terrifying apex hunter, now feels about as threatening as a malfunctioning parade float. Disney's influence hangs over the whole thing: every bold idea sanded down, every bit of personality replaced with something safe, sanitised, and painfully market-tested. As someone who grew up with these films, watching this felt strangely heartbreaking like coming home expecting something familiar and comforting, only to find it replaced with Snow White wearing a Predator mask. It left me with a genuine ache, almost like homesickness for a franchise that used to respect its own identity. And honestly, when will Disney learn that stripping away what made the original work special doesn't help anybody fans, newcomers, or the story itself?

This movie is worth a watch as the story is good along with the writing. I was reminded of how I felt when I had seen Star Wars: The Phantom Menace and trying to contemplate whether or not I liked it being a huge Star Wars fan. Predator: Badlands is like that movie in that it is another example of when a franchise just tries to get too cutesie and add humor to something that is not known for such. I was disappointed when I saw that this was PG-13 and not R. I wasn't disappointed with the movie as a whole but only in seeing that it lacked the bloody, gritty, testosterone-fueled feel of P1, P2 and Predators. I liked that the Weylan-Yutani storyline was included. Badlands is good if you want to take your kid to a lighter and more Disneyfied version of Predator before they're old enough to watch the original.

Let's be honest this is just a mix of Jurassic park, Avatar, Starwars all wrapped into one. With a predator falling in love with new pronoun. Hollywood really you need to wake up and go back to the 80s and 90s. We're just getting directors because they come from a certain place and not looking at true cinema.

Predator: Badlands opens a rare window into the inner world and culture of the Yautja. It succeeds at nearly everything it attempts: introducing fresh monsters, exploring Weyland-Yutani robotics, and expanding the universe in interesting ways.

I had such high hopes for this movie after Dan Trachtenberg drag the Predator franchise out of the gutter and restored it to its former glory with Prey. Well if Pray was Star Wars, Badlands is Episode II: Attack of the Clones. They tried to inject a lot of humour into this movie which just didn't work for me, and I didn't feel it should have had a place in this movie. I found some of it just ridiculous. The story is actually very good and could have been epic in the same way Prey was. Prey is an incredible movie in so many ways and I was expecting Badlands to be the same, sadly, for me it wasn't. There are good elements in this film such as gaining some insight into the Predators home world and culture. I also though Elle Fanning was fantastic in this movie. If Badlands had taken itself more seriously I would have liked it a whole lot more. I don't actually think the fault lays with Dan Trachtenberg This is a 12A in the UK and I'm pretty sure Disney were trying to make it appeal to children. So once again Disney take something wonderful and completely destroy it. I'd love to see Dan Trachtenberg original script and not the Disneyfied version.

Predator Badlands is a great example on how to take a franchise in a different direction. The pacing of the movie is fantastic. Right from the beginning you get some lovely Yautja lore and breathtaking action. The story is simple and it does a good job of getting you from point A to B with plenty of fun surprises along the way. The action is a standout and I wouldn't be dismayed by the PG-13 rating because the kills are still awesome. The only difference is nothing red spills out, the gore is green, blue, white and lots of alien guts. The creature design is also a standout throughout the movie as well. Without saying much more I've been a Predator fan since the Arnie original. Anything Predator and I'll buy a ticket, even if it's as terrible as Predator 2018 or AvP Requiem. Predator Badlands is an extremely entertaining blockbuster from start to finish. Full of excellent action sequences, pathos and beautiful vfx. Definitely go see this in the theatre's if you're a fan, even if you have any trepidation regarding the creative decisions. I still think many Predator fans will find something to enjoy in Predator Badlands. Highly recommended.

I have conflicted feelings about this one. There's a strong sense of immaturity watching this film, the Disneyfication of Predator franchise, there's no denying that. We have the classic Disney theme of friends on an adventure, with cute xeno-species and plenty of morale-preaching and for-exposition-only dialogue you'd think a Predator would put an end to with a well aimed shot from a shoulder-mounted plasma cannon. There's even a couple of shots copying (or was it stealing?) from the Fellowship of the Ring, with the fellowship advancing along a mountain ridge path (you'll know it when you see it).

Predator: Badlands is pure adrenaline from start to finish! I've watched every movie in the franchise, and this one instantly became one of my favorites. The action scenes are brutal and thrilling, the setting is awesome, and the Predator looks more menacing than ever. You can feel the tension in every moment, and it keeps you on the edge of your seat. Everything about this movie just works - the story, the visuals, the atmosphere. I loved every second of it. If you're a true Predator fan, this one's a must-watch!
The Evidence
This movie was oddly heartwarming and touching in places.
This movie could have been amazing. Just the mere concept of telling a Yatkuja story is bold, and makes this worth a watch. However, it didn't quite follow through.
Disney is broken. It's a factory that's recycled its own garbage so many times that they don't know how to make anything other than garbage.

If there's ever been a film that carries the name "Predator" yet completely fails to grasp even the most basic essence of the franchise - its rhythm, atmosphere, or sense of threat - that film is undoubtedly Predator: Badlands. At best, it can be described as a failed exercise in mimicking a legend - a film devoid of the Predator's spirit, menace, and that primal suspense that defined the originals.

First thing's first: I'm not a paid influencer shill, most of Disney's recent theatrical output has been fairly substandard and Bob Iger's pledge to integrate AI-generated content into his precious little streaming is nothing short of an insult to the human passion and creativity that Walt himself imbued into this company.
