The Animation
The Adventure
The Comedy
The Voice Acting
The New Song
The Pace
The Heart
The References
Summary:
Disney has so much technology to animate at their hands, and it continues to show that off with this film. Smooth movements, a colorful design, and plenty of character in the motions, Zootopia 2 is a gorgeous display of what is possible with their resources, giving the audience plenty to look, gawk, and enjoy as the multi-biome city returns once more to the big screens. Within this environmental playground is an adventure that feels a bit bigger and more explored than the previous film's montage did. We dive into a few more secrets and environmental factors, playing around with the fauna that is indigenous to them, adapting to the needs as the wild adventure unsheathes its claws. It goes more down the traditional Disney route to teach lessons, but not be so in your face like the first film, which opens up a bit more of an escape from the real world. And helping to keep things fun is comedy that is present in so many forms that it's hard not to find some style to have you cracking up in the theater. Kids are going to become infatuated with a lot of the silliness invoked, and many of the parents will probably get pulled into the fervor with them and making many Instagram/TikTok videos to mimic them. My favorite part had to be the references. Like Wish, Zootopia 2 is ready to poke fun at Disney's work, and you'll find references abound within the two hours as another collective "cameo" menagerie is integrated into the movie. Mostly comedic, sometimes emotional, these references serve as another angle to enjoy the film for a geek like me. All of this is done at a decent pace, an adventure to follow in a manner that doesn't feel slow, and relatively keeps things in check to not be extremely fast you have no content.

Zootopia 2 restores Disney animation to its former glory with a high quality sequel that plays to the exact same strengths as the original but doesn't repeat itself thematically. This is another really funny and fast paced adventure where Nick Wilde & Judy Hopps unravel an equally sinister yet more mature conspiracy which goes to the very top, now focused on how the rich use gentrification to expand their ambitions at the expense of those who are different, covering it all up by erasing history with propaganda afterwards.

I'm going to be honest, I haven't been impressed with Disney's performance lately. I was concerned that they'd screw this up. My fears were unfounded. It's not common to find a movie which is as much fun to watch as it feels like the cast and crew had making it. Zootopia 2 is a movie about reconciling differences and discusses our modern society without getting preachy. It's a love letter to past Disney films and the art with references and cameos galore.

As an adult who hasn't watched disney movie for a while, i gotta say that i didn't expect much from this movie. However, this movie exceeded my expectations by adding the issues on childhood trauma and personality disorders into the script. The details, music, and several hidden references along with a pretty solid plot are combined beautifully.
"Zootopia 2"-a cool breeze of winds that is filled with memories, twists, some sparking chemistry, and an amusing story!

Zootopia 2 is a decent and mostly enjoyable sequel, but after such a long wait, it's hard not to feel a little let down. The original film genuinely surprised me with how clever, heartfelt, and layered it was. This follow-up brings back the familiar charm, but never quite captures the same magic. It mostly feels more like a safe sequel of a successful brand than a story that really needed to be told.

I guess one advantage of animated movies is that you can release a sequel nine years after the original and have the storyline only take place a week after the first film, but it still feels like Zootopia 2 could have advanced the plot a bit more. It feels like this movie is riding the coattails of its predecessor and using a lot of the same themes it did before. It also isn't as fun or whimsical as Zootopia. There are humorous moments, but the overall tone is fairly serious. I like the animation, the characters, the new song, and the expanded universe. There just isn't much to love about Zootopia 2.

Zootopia 2 is honestly one of the best sequels Disney has released, and it delivers laughs from start to finish. If the first movie had a great balance of humor and heart, this one pushes the comedy even further while still keeping the emotional moments strong. Judy and Nick are back with even better chemistry than before, and their comedic timing is perfect-every joke lands, every reaction is hilarious, and even the new characters add to the comedy without feeling forced.

Its not as cute and the story isnt as powerful. The first truly took me by suprise. This just seemed like s forced story to extend a successful franchise. It included some fun characters, but the whole police academy part seemed like a fail. Bad guys totally knocks this out of the park now. Thats the series you should pick over this one.

I loved the first movie for the character and world building, the humour and especially for the time the movie gives to its story and us, the viewers, to process everything. And we all remember the scenes of her alone in her room in the big city or the very slow moving sloths vs. The impatient bunny. Since the world and characters have been established, the second movie starts with action and doesn't stop with it until it reaches the final quarter. It's a very hectic movie with only very few scenes where it gives you time to process. Iconic scenes, like the mentioned one from the first movie, are missing and the humour is also just hectic and plain unfunny, to me - and compared to the humour of the first movie. This seems to be a pattern at Disney, because Moana 2 also just was more hectic with less story and less character building moments.
Zootopia 2 is probably one of the better films to have come out of the Disney fold.
Before I review, I must say, I haven't watched Zootopia 2's prequel and the last movie that I watched, with this style, was Toy Story back when I was a teenager.

Never thought that the sequel would be better than original. Sequel have everything, incredible world expansion (like it's MASSIVE), jokes are funnier and the relationship between Nick and Judy is the best part, also i absolutely love a new characters like Garry, Nibbles, Mayor Winddancer and ofc the Lynxley family (All of them). The movie references was perfect and especially one for an all time horror classic, if you're a fan of the first one ran as fast as you can to see it.

Unfortunately Disney still rolling with hyperspeed gag machines instead of actual fully fletched movies. This movie must have atleast 100 gags and half of them are easter eggs or references to other movies. It gets very frustating as every good film making bit and scene gets cheaped out by either gags or constant "action". When characters are glumsy for millionth time and it adds 0 story or character value, you just feel numb.

I don't know if this is because I grow up. I think this one is like mid. Good part is the attention to details as always. So precise for describing the animals. I really like the snakes voice it is better than I expected. The plot does not feel as strong as the first one. The new characters overall do not feel as good as the old ones. But I like it in Dolby the color is good.

Zootopia 2 (a follow-up to Zootopia (2016)) follows the cop duo Judy (the do-good bunny) and Nick (the shifty fox) as they navigate their new partnership, make friends along the way, and uncover hidden secrets. But, at what cost???

I was not excited to see this, (I watch a fraction of all the animated movies with my kids) but I was pleasantly surprised and laughed a ton. I was not bored at all and enjoyed all of the references. The movies had lots of surprises and great overall theme and message. The only disappointment was the mid song. With Ed Sheeran and Shakira writing and performing I would think they could do better.

Zootopia 2 puts a lot of effort into its visuals, and the recreation of Zootopia is impressive. The city looks great, and revisiting familiar places is enjoyable. However, despite being set in the same locations, the film doesn't connect strongly enough to the first movie, which weakens the sense of continuity.

It's crazy to think it's been nine years since the original, but we finally have a much-needed sequel to one of my favorite movies of all time-and the wait was absolutely worth it. We got another perfect film that continues the story in such a natural way, expanding the universe with new worlds and characters, while once again diving deep into important themes like prejudice and bias, social divisions, community trust and policing, diversity and inclusion, cooperation, misinformation and media influence, personal growth and identity, and political and societal change. All of this is delivered through wonderful writing filled with humor, adventure, action, mystery, twists, emotional moments, and so much more. You almost forget you're watching an animated movie because everything is executed so well.

Zootopia 2 is a BLAST!!! Honestly after being disappointed by Disney Animation's last three outings, I had low to moderate expectations going in to Zootopia 2, but it not only met those expectations, it exceeded them. This was worth the 9 year wait. Let's talk about what works so well about the movie.

My wife and I recently watched Zootopia 2 (2025) in theaters last night. The storyline follows Nick Wild and Judy Hopps fresh off being recognized from their amazing accomplishments. Their next big case doesn't go as planned and they find hints of something that hasn't been seen in Zootopia in maybe a hundred years...a snake. While they get punished for their latest case going array, they dig into this snake matter and the secrets around it.

"Zootopia 2" is a delightful and well-crafted sequel that builds on everything that made the first film special while taking Judy and Nick into newer, bigger emotional territory. The story dives deeper into their partnership as they face a more complex mystery that challenges not just their skills as officers but their trust in each other. The film expands the world of Zootopia with new districts, richer social themes, and memorable new characters who add both humor and heart. The chemistry between Judy and Nick remains the highlight-full of warmth, wit, and genuine affection. The animation is stunning, the pacing tight, and the humor cleverly sprinkled without overshadowing the story's strong emotional core. While it may not surpass the originality of the first film, "Zootopia 2" succeeds as a vibrant, meaningful, and thoroughly entertaining follow-up that leaves you smiling long after it ends.

title: Doctor Who: The Fourth Doctor Adventures

review_text: Song Sung Blue is an initially heartwarming but ultimately very emotional journey that is all the better for exploring the affection people have for Neil Diamond's music by showing the highs and lows of a more ordinary couple's life. There's a wholesomeness in watching Lightning & Thunder find love as they simultaneously start to fulfill their dreams in later life which exacerbates how almost overwhelmingly devastating it is when life deals them such an awful hand.
Another mystery movie sneak preview, but going into it I was 99% confident it was going to be Song Sung Blue (secretly I was hoping for Marty Supreme)

Greetings again from the darkness. 'Do what you love' and 'Pursue your passion.' That's the traditional advice we give youngsters, so they won't grow up to live a mundane life filled with regrets. Perhaps there is no better example of living your dream than the real-life love story of Mike Sardina and Claire Stengl-Sardina. These two Milwaukee residents not only found a path to sing on stage, they also found true love with each other.

The events in Song Sung Blue really happened. I was there as a fan in the '90's and it was crazy. Crazy fun, crazy entertaining and, off-stage, crazy tragic at times. The real "Lightning and Thunder's" performances were uplifting - you left singing and dancing and in a great mood. The movie brought back that time and feeling.

Gen-X checking in. I loved this film! I have seen over 180 screenings in the theatre this year, this is easily one of the best of 2025. I wouldn't call myself a Neil Diamond fan, but enjoyed some of the greatest hits over the years. You do not need to be a fan to enjoy this film. This is the only film this year that hit my heart like this, bringing happy tears, sad tears... this was a tearjerker, bring the tissues. Kate Hudson should win best actress of the year. Great chemistry between the leads. The supporting cast is amazing as well. Great music, great drama, with several unexpected twists. A true Christmas film that has lots of heart and changes the viewer by the time they leave the theatre. Highly recommend!

This highly entertaining and unique musical story gives both Hugh Jackman and Kate Hudson the opportunity to shine in complex character roles. While the theme, script, and direction occasionally feel a bit cheesy, the film ultimately delivers an authentic sense of realism as it explores the struggles of this family and their triumphant connection to music. (Your kids may also become Neil Diamond fans and you will probably find yourself pulling up his greatest hits on you Apple Music account on the drive home from theater.)
Very rare that I can see a film without seeing the trailer beforehand, but somehow, I managed it here and knew almost nothing about what "Song Sung Blue" was actually about before going in.

Much better than your typical "based on a true story" movie. Kate Hudson really delivers an incredible performance adding a palpable extra dimension to her character on screen. Well balanced story telling, character development and a great cast quickly get you engrossed in the story and wishing for more.

It's a romantic musical drama based on a Neil Diamond tribute band called Lightning (Hugh Jackman) and Thunder (Kate Hudson), based in Wisconsin in the 1990s. Lightning/Mike Sardina is a divorced alcoholic Vietnam vet who works as a mechanic and a "Legends" tribute artist in the Milwaukee area. He has one daughter, Angelina (King Princess). Thunder/Claire Sardina meets Mike while she is doing a Patsy Cline impersonation at the Wisconsin State Fair. She has two kids, Rachel (Ella Anderson) and Dayna (Hudson Hensley). Other key characters are fellow impersonators, Mark (Michael Imperioli) and Sex Machine (Mustafa Shakir), and Lightning and Thunder's manager, Tom D'Amato (Jim Belushi). The film follows their romantic relationship and growing regional success until two tragic events impact them.

I'll admit, I walked into the theater with the wrong expectations. I expected a deep dive into the musical genius of Neil Diamond; instead, I was met with a love story that is strikingly real, raw, and human. While the music of Neil Diamond provides the soul of the film, the heart belongs to Mike and Claire Sardina.
This is a fine enough movie. Not groundbreaking and great like "One Battle After Another" but a good watch. You can kind of predict how things will go, but that's okay.

A man, Lightning, and a woman, Thunder, find love and a chance at their dreams in together creating a tribute "experience" to Neil Diamond. They are working class people--and I expect there to be a wink by the filmmakers, a bit of condescension, "isn't this goofy?" tone. There is NO SUCH THING. This is a fun and uplifting and sincere and dramatic and refreshing film. Both Hugh Jackman and Kate Hudson have tremendous voices and stage presence galore. Everybody else is great, too. Writer/director Craig Brewer is to be congratulated for turning his vision into great cinema. Great? Great!!!

As a Milwaukee native I saw Lightening and Thunder perform at various venues around town over the years. I was very familiar with their story prior to seeing the film. Although the film does an adequate job of re-telling their story a lot of the factual details were changed and some were excluded. I would encourage anyone who enjoyed the Hollywood film version to check out the original documentary that was done on the couple back in 2008. It is available on YouTube under the same title "Song Sung Blue".

Unbelievable! If Hugh Jackman and Kate Hudson don't receive an Oscar for their performances (or at the very least a nomination), then I've lost faith in the movie community. It really amazes me the talent these two actors have. I was very impressed with the whole movie and very entertained. The music is incredible and even if you don't know Neil Diamond songs, you just might find yourself humming or singing along. And the movie was "clean". No F words flying around, no nudity, no sex (except for a small make-out session - but with underwear on!). I was so pleased with this movie. An absolute gem! GO SEE!!!!

From alcoholic baseball fans who won't stop singing "Sweet Caroline" even when you tell them to for just one inning to that old guy in your building who still plays and quietly weeps to his cherished vinyl of "The Jazz Singer," except for "Saving Silverman" and that part you generally skip in "The Last Waltz" this is the ultimate film for Neil Diamond fans. As Milwaukee Neil devotee Mike, Hugh Jackman trades his Logan lamb chops for that amazing Neil hairdo you usually only see on Mexican detention officers to sing Diamond's hits with a true showman's devotion; his maniacal, Wolvie-like intensity just makes one wish that proposed 'Klaus Kinski as Wayne Newton' biopic had gotten off the ground. And Kate Hudson with her usual 'entitled python about to devour a litter of kittens' charm just shines as his fellow devotee and wife Claire. They truly are Lightning and Thunder, and they got the way to move me. This is going to be the monster hit of the holidays, and they come to America (only to be shipped right back) for "Song Sung Blue."
Based on a true story?? Wow, what an incredible story with all the emotions that felt like a roller-coaster, which life can throw your way.

It's a good music biopic that, in essence, doesn't offer anything new and follows the typical trend of such films. If you're a Neil Diamond fan, you'll definitely enjoy it. The acting is strong. Personally, I think Hugh Jackman is very underrated-most of the praise went to Kate Hudson-but Jackman also has many wonderful moments. I'm surprised he didn't even get a Golden Globe nomination. The only downside was his hairstyle; otherwise, it was a very, very good performance.

This movie should be seen by everyone whether you love Neil Diamond or not. It has tremendous heart, charismatic and brilliant performances, great chemistry between Kate and Hugh. You'll laugh and prob cry but never a dull moment or false note. The young actors were all great and so fun seeing Michael Imperioli, Jim Belushi, Fisher Stevens . Look out for the oscar noms on this one!!

Thought the film was a bit over the top. The idea of Lightning marrying Thunder was a bit crazy considering the age difference. Since I paid 20.00 to see it, I just wanted to say that Kate Hudson deserves an Oscar nomination here. Her singing is actually her, along with the Wisconsin accent. Seems Lightning (Jackman) had no money and was living off of her the time they were married. I know they make big bucks, etc. Just give Hudson some recognition. We haven't seen her in years.
What a thoroughly enjoyable and wholesome film. I was genuinely surprised by just how much I enjoyed it.

It's difficult to quantify the profound influence music has on mental health, or the transformative power it holds over cinema. Just as changing a single note in an orchestration can shift the entire mood of a piece, this film captures life's shifting seasons through bittersweet moments and unanswered questions. Told through the lens of a professional musician, the film delivers a vital message: if you aren't "enough" for yourself, music will never be enough to fill the void. Kate Hudson and Hugh Jackman deliver elevated performances that ground the film's artistic style. While many musical biographies feel repetitive, this is a rare entry in the genre. It is a cautionary tale that remains planted in solid values, expertly balancing emotional weight with accessibility. It never becomes overly sentimental, nor does it get so lost in its period setting that it alienates a modern audience.

What a wonderful and emotional movie. I believe its fairly true to the real life story, so I hope Neil Diamond approved! All of the actors were great, with Hugh Jackman in full 'Greatest Showman' mode, but Kate Hudson was a revelation...who knew she had such a great voice. Her final song left the whole audience in tears, simply beautiful.

This is the cringiest thing I've seen in a while, but also much better than I expected. It actually ends up being a very good movie. Song Sung Blue follows a familiar and relatively easy path, but one that proves effective thanks to its emotional pull.
Superb audio drama about CIA, from the perspective of Eloise Page.

I listen to audio books all the time because I can't read a book during the day (at work). I love them and this one was no exception. It was well written, great performances by the actors and I listened to the whole thing in two sittings, it was that good. It was just the right amount of suspense, the right amount of science fiction, the right amount of excitement, sadness, and happiness. I can't wait for the a sequel. I hope there will be one. One recommendation is that there was more of a pre-story or background at the beginning concerning the Dr.s relationships. Overall very interesting and well done. Bravo!
Now if we can only get the TV show adaptation, that would be great. I thought the voice-over castings were spot on. Paul has a powerful voice and I honestly could picture him as the detective he is.

Perfect tone. I love scifi and fantasy and this has just the little taste you need with a fun backstory, engaging comedic performances by a cast of stars, and an ease of entry unlike many other narrative pods I've listened to. Like a more well-realized 'Welcome to Nightvale' type show. Really funny, really great listen. Would recommend.

Bobby Moynihan is the funniest guy ever, he'd be funny saying anything. So when you combine him with clever writing and a great premise it's super-funny. Stanland is about a podcaster who accidentally goes into a fantasy realm and learns that a guy named Stan is already there, and is actively ruining everything. Highly recommended!
The ease and ace with which Tatiana dives in to each character she portrays is phenomenal. You end up rooting for her against her own portrayal until you realize you've dug in so deep.

My shelf is full of Batman comics and figures and what have you. I know Batman. This podcast is a unique and familiar experience that is worth a listen, especially after the first two episodes. The odd start made me think one thing and the twist following episode 2 had me thinking another. Worth it for sure. Some may knock it for the lack of Bat but do give it a chance.

"Batman Unburied" is a new and fresh take on the character of Bruce Wayne. It's something you probably haven't heard before - but that doesn't mean that it strays too far away that it has hardly anything to do with Batman or the "Bat-Verse".
I'm not really into Audiobooks but thought I would give this a go today while I was out walking, wow a good solid first 2 episodes.
I just listened to the 1st part this morning on the bus to work...very gripping with a fantastic cast...well worth a listen to...a very different take on the batman.

I couldn't help but notice some 1-star reviews that CLEARLY didn't listen past the first episode... Because their reasonings for not liking the show are void after 2 episodes. (MINOR SPOILER ABOUT FIRST EPISODE) the first episode is meant to be a little jarring- so if you're confused, good- it means you're a Batman fan and you should be a little confused.

After listening to all the podcast episodes till now, I can say that it is a true psychological thriller audio series and those who are a big fan of Batman or DC then this podcast is rightfully dedicated to them. Sometimes I get into the series during some interesting conversation but sometimes because of some conversations, the whole link of interest breaks and that is where I felt that it should not be there.

+ves
1) the idea of Bruce as a principled goth mortician would've been excellent if not for twist ruining it.

Look, the character of Batman has been around for 83 years. There have been numerous books, treatises, or dissertations regarding the psyche of the essence. We know all of that, and like the shows "Gotham" or "Krypton," if the "guy" isn't there, we don't care! I know this is early days but if he isn't present, neither will we be present.

A masterful adaptation of Neil Gaiman's Sandman. I'm a lifelong fan of Gaiman's work, from Neverwhere to American Gods, but Sandman is my absolute favorite piece. The direction, the voice acting, the narration from Gaiman himself is top tier entertainment. Something to enjoy before the Netflix series premieres this winter!

This audio book series I guess you could call it was breathtaking. The way that each and every character had a nuance to them and development was breathtaking. I could not stop listening and falling deep in the stories and the beauty of them all 10 out of 10 would deff recommend.

I understand why it's taken so long to have these tales translated into film, if it is to be done properly. I was worried about losing the feeling of "place" in an audio version, but the production, cast, and of course the Narrator himself have done an amazing job with one of my favorite series of all time. Thank you.
As an old Gaiman fan, I was hopeful about this audio book and it is so far way better than I've hoped for.

My first audio book and where do I go from here!?! Absolutely blown away. Mr. Gaiman, you are an absolute genius. The casting and performances are perfection. James McAvoy as Morpheus .....drew me into a story like never before. The level of creativity and imagination in The Sandman boggles my mind. It was like seeing and feeling the sun for the first time. And the "cereal" conference actually frightened me....something that's not easy to do
Thank you yo everyone who made this masterpiece!

Still working my way through the dramatization, and rereading the graphic novels just prior. The voice actors, sound editors and other production specialists have done a fantastic job of bringing Gaiman's masterpiece to life. After years of production hell of attempts to turn the series into a movie or television show, it appears they've finally found the ideal medium.

I kept getting the feeling that this show would step out of my interest at many points. Yet I kept eagerly hitting next episode after each. I will watch this one again now that Im familiar with its style and I expect I will enjoy it even more. It was a weird one and I found it compelling.

WATCHHHHH!! Reviews are subjective, I typically don't listen to other's reviews if I want to see something. I'm so glad I didn't listen...this series is effortlessly acted & written the actors are PERFECT. It's been a long time since I've been transported to another realm & didn't realize it. I'd feel like a sell out if I didn't mention that this is the first series where I didn't feel like they just threw a Black person in for a quota, I actually didn't notice race in a world that's obsessed with it. I just enjoyed the storyline and rift's the cinema magic. You owe it to yourself to be entertained PEOPLE!!!
One of the best things that ever happened since Sandman, the graphic novel series. I am so glad that this audiobook came into being. I am so glad that I share this planet with Neil Gaiman.
Great adaptation! The voices, the atmosphere, everything is great!
It's Beautiful with lots of contrast and characteristics of the story holds truly amazing and acknowledging more than I could ever thought. My favorite part is starting of the story.

I came to The Sandman later than most and fell under its spell straight away. The imagination of Neil Gaiman to bring this modern day epic into reality was simply terrifying, intriguing and beautiful all at the same time.
How many times I praised Sandman to anyone I met. Then explaining comic book made for audio book. How? Why?
The story from the books was well represented, Gaiman is a masterful storyteller.
I dont think I could have enjoyed this show more.
So many good things happen! From good plots/dialogue to excellently well-executed scenes and fight scenes you just can't help yourself to watching more! Can't wait for it to be renewed!

The story is good, but the production quality is amazing. I've never experienced an audio drama with no narration, but this podcast does just that. The story really unfolds in your mind's eye through nothing but dialog and sound effects. It's brilliant, actually, and listening through headphones enhances the experience. A character comes through a door and you hear the door and the voice on one side, then the voice moves to the middle as the character fully joins the scene. I'm really enjoying it, and if I hadn't started right after the first episode was released, I'm sure it have binged all that were available.

I did not expect to be a fan of this. Super high quality production and great casting. So entertaining. More of this format please!! Yeah the initial trailer did not inspire me but the actual podcast is GREAT. The casting choices are also inspired. Naveen is terrific in this role. There is such room for this kind of storytelling in this day of "streaming is too expensive" and everything is in danger of getting cancelled or never green lit. With podcasting of this quality which has to be enormously less expensive it could be a whole new entertainment world.

This podcast series is surprisingly compact thus very attractive to a modern literature and art consumer, so it didn't take me long to finish it. It's hard to use the word 'enjoy' given the context and the outcome of this classical piece but it definitely touched me as well as kept me tense and all ears. Both Andrews (Garfield and Scott) are fantastic: each of their words, sounds they uttered was permeated with their character's living essence whereas - it was most likely decided that way - Cynthia Erivo as Julia remained more distant and sober, which was probably a good balance. They got carried away, in my opinion, with the number of layers of sound audible at the same time (telescreens speaking, rattlings, street noises, yelling and shouting, etc.); it could have been a bit cleaner and clearer by the rule "less is more" but probably this exaggeration was part of the programme. But all in all, great work, highly recommended, especially if you're a fan of either of the Andrews or/and into noticing how at this very moment, 40 years after 1984, - at least some parts of - the world are falling thick and fast into this horrifying i-love-big-brother reality.

Joachim Trier's films concern themselves with the quiet crises that shape a life. His work is marked by an unusual balance of intellectual rigor and emotional generosity: formally precise yet deeply humane, ironic without cynicism and always attentive to the small, decisive moments where lives tilt almost imperceptibly. Throughout his career, he has shown a deep attunement to the ways people try to make sense of themselves amid the shifting currents of memory and expectation.

'Sentimental Value (2025)' is a drama about a filmmaker who seeks to cast his semi-estranged daughter in the lead role of his most personal project to date. As Joachim Trier's follow-up to 'The Worst Person In The World (2021)', I can't deny that it's vaguely disappointing. That may be because nothing, not even a rewatch of that movie, could recreate the feeling that Trier's superior prior picture stirred in me when I first watched it, but it's still something worth mentioning considering a lot of people will likely be in the same position as me. Having said that, this latest effort seems to be moving a lot of people quite a lot, and most who see it seem to think it's a masterpiece. Perhaps my slight disconnect with it is more due to my own expectations than any actual flaws of the feature, but I do feel like the flick struggles to come together with a cohesive point or message and ultimately leaves me a little cold. It's still a really well-made and well-performed picture that's satisfyingly subtly meta and generally well-observed, with tangible relationships and several really poignant musings on life and the ways in which we navigate through it. Intermittently funny and equally as often moving, the movie is slightly too long but always at least somewhat compelling. The main dynamic at its core is a father-daughter scenario, but the narrative's most emotionally affecting relationship to me is its sister bond. The experience is more than capable of focusing on multiple relationships, and this complexity is a marker of its general nuance and gentle profundity, but I can't help but feel like it isn't quite sure who it wants its main character to be and it doesn't spend enough time with the daughter of its father-daughter rapport for its emotional payoff to hit as hard as it's clearly intended to. Despite my hesitations with some of it, this is a really solid effort all around. It's moving, it's funny, it's well-crafted and expertly performed. Its emotional effect is relatively minor for me personally, but it's an engaging and often beautiful affair that will surely mean a lot to a lot of people. It's good.
The movie is blessed with a strong scenario that would have excelented as a novella. The director/co-writer leaves just enough room to keep the audience wandering.

Poignant, beautifully acted, and visually stunning, the movie captures the complexity of human connection with rare honesty. Every scene feels lived-in, every line of dialogue rings true, and the way it unfolds keeps you emotionally invested all the way through. Definitely the best movie I've watched this year!
:::Watched at Scandinavian Film Festival:::

Sentimental Value is a multi-layered masterpiece of a film that skillfully shows several generations of a family affected by both historical and personal traumas. The film focuses on two of the generations: father and two daughters living their life in modern Norway and dealing with the emotional baggage from their past in very different ways. The film honestly opens the door for us into this family house so that we see things the way they are, no character is judged or mocked here. Yet, the storytelling itself has its own twists, therefore we can get the pieces together towards the end, which makes this film even more wholesome and delicate. Amazing script, wonderful acting, great choice of music. Bravo!
In this lovely tradition of watching films during awards season, because we allow ourselves to see movies we might not otherwise watch, we come across "Sentimental Value."

Sentimental Values has been praised left and right as a masterpiece, but for me it lands more in the category of "good, but not great." It's beautifully made, with a strong pace, a well-crafted script and strong acting, giving the story authenticity and emotional weight from beginning to end.
This is the kind of film that, while watching it, makes you want to be part of the filmmaking process-writing, directing, acting.

Sentimental Value is about a father and his two adult daughters, each reflecting on their past family lives. The father is a film director, absorbed with a new idea for a film, one which seems to be a dramatic representation of a crucial incident in his earlier life. One daughter has acted in the past, the other is currently an actor, performing in a Chekhov play. The father introduces his daughters to a young American actor, played by Elle Fanning, whom he intends to have as the key actor in his new film, representing, it seems, one of his daughters. She may or may not be the father's latest partner. The daughters want to keep their distance both from their father and any involvement in their father's film. Cinematography and acting are of a high standard. But in the end the script doesn't hang together sufficiently well to give a coherent picture of Joachim Trier's intended theme. It looks good, it's interesting, but where's its centre?

This is the first time i rate a movie on imdb. I watched it on cinema a couple of days ago and it is by far the best movie I have ever seen in my life. It's still stuck in my body, even from seeing it two days ago. Really, a masterpiece... Renate is perfect for the role, also the other actors makes it whole. I love how you can almost touch and feel the mood in the movie. Joachim Trier has done it again. This is Oscar worthy, and I hope everyone is watching this at least one time in their life.

At first, I thought the disappointment was on me for expecting too much. I'd really liked Joachim Trier's Oslo trilogy, especially The Worst Person in the World, so I was down for a new film from him, especially with this cast. I guess it being called Sentimental Value, I was also expecting an emotional walloping I never really got. That sense of not feeling the movie might be partly on me for expecting something else, but I think it's also partly on the movie for not being more than, at best, pretty good.

I watched this movie at the theaters on 12/04/2025, right before this review. In the end, I give this one a slightly above-average score - 5.5/10 . The main problem, I guess, is that I probably just didn't get it. And I'm not ashamed to say so

Although there are obvious comparisons with Ingmar Bergman's masterworks, this 2025 Norwegian drama reminded me more of the way Yasujiro Ozu approached storytelling in his films through quiet scenes that insinuate and then emotionally strike in unexpected ways. Director Joachim Trier and screenwriter Eskil Vogt bring a similar dynamic by introducing life's complications into a richly textured story of two sisters, Nora and Agnes, dealing with the return of their estranged father, Gustav Borg, a renowned filmmaker who decides after a long break, to make a film ostensibly about his mother but really about the daughters. He wants Nora, an accomplished stage actress, to star, but upon her immediate refusal, he casts Rachel Kemp, a popular American actress instead. Meanwhile, Agnes, who is married with a young son and decidedly not in the business, takes tentative steps to get closer with him but faces her own struggles with his emotional interference. As the film within the film develops, the lines between life and art get blurrier and blurrier, and Trier even borrows an appropriate allusion to Bergman's "Persona". There are also welcome, unexpected laughs along the way as well. As Borg, Stellan Skarsgård strikes the right balance between megalomania bluster and vulnerability. The three actresses are all superb. Renate Reinsve gives an incisive portrait of an actress caught in a maelstrom of conflicting emotions, while Inga Ibsdotter Lilleaas brings credible warmth with subtle moments of rancor to the less showy role of Agnes. The biggest surprise is Elle Fanning who doesn't play Rachel as commercial and vacuous but rather as conscientious and conflicted. The technical elements are aces, in particular, Kasper Tuxen's cinematography, Olivier Bugge Coutté's fluid film editing, and Jørgen Stangebye Larsen's pristine production design.

Sentimental Value reflects Joachim Trier's Norwegian cultural environment while exploring the psychology of generational trauma. With nuance and compassion, the film shows how parents' choices reverberate through their children's lives, shaping identity and memory. Trier suggests that reconciliation across generations, though fragile, is possible. I found this movie both profound and tender. It triggered long conversations with my wife about our own lives and efforts to raise our children in a supportive and loving environment through both happy and challenging times.
I'm often bemused by reviews in here from people who go to a film and then give it a low rating because it wasn't like every other movie they like.

From the very beginning, the writing makes a concerted effort to delve deep into the characters' psyches. It seeks to explore the pain and lingering recollections of a past long buried, memories that continue to haunt the group of protagonists and hinder their ability to function effectively at both their personal and professional podiums.
Why do genius film artists like Norway's Jochim Trier make movies like "Sentimental Value"?

It was such a pleasure to see a movie that does not follow an American Aesthetic. It covers some familiar themes concerning old people trying to live their more productive pasts , think of the athlete that can't 'hang up the cleats'. And throw in the difficult emotions of children who have grown up and can't really come to terms with their less than ideal childhoods and the current state of their relationships with parents. The film is at once raw, hard hitting and and still shows great tenderness in the human relationships on display. The acting / character portrayals are positively first rate. The last 45 minutes of the film are what make it truly 'good'. You think you understand the last scene and will be surprised even though it makes sense. It would be eight Stars except it is a bit slow moving in the beginning and does not flow as well as it might with better editing. Remember . . . When . . . We . . . Had . . . Art House theaters ? We don't get nearly enough fare like this movie anymore.

The film starts with promise. I genuinely appreciated the tension in the theatre scene involving the second daughter. Unfortunately, that was the only part that did. The rest of the film feels stagnant: the script drags, and the direction never truly engages. You keep waiting for a climax, for a turning point that would justify the slow build-up, but it never really arrives.

I felt this needed a review so i made an user. First timer here. Usually dont go to cinema. Watched «verdens verste menneske». Loved it. Sentimental value is more personal. I think its impossible not to Get affected in some way Even though you had a great upbringing( i had). Kinda slow in the beginning but builds up. Centers around the father to daughter relationship. I didnt go into this watching reviews. . The director said before the movie «i hope you feel something». This is a hit or miss movie. This is a hit It delivers in the end. We live in such a shallow world. This offers depth. I Even cried.

I had a really fun time with this movie. The suspense works, the gore is satisfyingly bloody, and while the chimp looks very cheesy, that honestly adds to the charm rather than hurting it. At a tight 90-minute runtime, it doesn't waste time-things get intense fast, and once they do, the movie never lets up until the end. It's mean, messy, and fully commits to its ridiculous premise in the best way.
This movie was exactly what I thought it would be. Don't expect an Oscar worthy performance from any of the actors. To be honest they dont matter as much as the primate.

Saw "Primate" - it was the Cinemark $5 secret movie last night. In this one, it is "Cujo" except with a chimpanzee instead of a dog and with a larger cast. Cast includes Troy Kotsur from "Coda" and Johnny Sequoyah from "Dexter: New Blood". The chimp is a motion capture of Miguel Torres Umba ala Andy Serkis from LOTR. Anyway, the movie has a surfeit of gore for horror fans and there is truly suspenseful denouncement where Kotsur's deafness plays a role. There are of course some actions by the characters that defy common sense as well actions by the chimp that don't seem possible - but that is what "artistic license" is all about. The script is average, and the direction is competent but not extraordinary. I am not sure I would have paid full price for this one, but it is probably worth a matinee or better yet, wait for streaming. 6/10.
6.9/10 (7) (Definitely Recommend)

When I heard about this movie I figured it would be pretty bad but it's actually a decent film but it's nothing noteworthy to be honest. I feel like first off the movie is really intense at times and Ben is quite intimidating at times throughout the movie and the film really has some nice cinematography which elevates the scares in this film here. Obviously the movie is at its best when Ben is hunting down our characters and just being an absolute menace but the film gets quite messy with a really weird storyline and there's lots of plot holes which just don't get resolved and it really left me scratching my head while watching the film. Most of the characters are pretty forgettable as well for the most part and they make quite literally the stupidest choices ever. Lucy played by Johnny Sequoyah is quite easily like the only character who's actually interesting and I actually really liked her character in this film and some of the family dynamics help the film but some of these moments felt pointless. I'll also give the film some credit because I really loved the soundtrack in this film and it was really eerie at moments which I just absolutely loved so honestly shoutout Adrian Johnston for the soundtrack because I loved what they did here. The movie also has some decent horror throughout the move and some moments felt really cheap but those other moments felt really scary and terrifying at times. I also really liked the practical effects here and they looked absolutely amazing with all of the kills throughout the movie as well. Overall this movie isn't bad but it's a decent time and I think this movie is worth checking out if you're a big horror fan!

The movie is based on a monkey with rabies in a "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" gruesome-type horror movie. Each individual's death is unique and very gruesome. How you survive in a isolated/remote location with a raging monkey? Watch the movie and find out. I had an opportunity to attend a pre showing and enjoyed it.

I had the opportunity to see an early screening of Primate at my local theater. It was surprisingly way scarier than I thought it would be and I had an amazing time. There is something terrifying about a pet turning against you and behaving like a monster. It had many campy and funny moments as well which I did enjoy. I think its not an award winning film but it is guaranteed to be an enjoyable time at the multiplex.

Who knew having opposable thumbs could be so scary? Usually, January has been known to be a dumping ground for not-the-best movies. Of course, there are some exceptions. The new horror PRIMATE might be one of these for you. Lucy (Johnny Sequoyah) comes home from college to her sister Erin (Gia Hunter), their father Adam (Troy Kotsur), and their friends. Another member of the family is Ben (Miguel Torres Umba), a very smart chimpanzee. When Ben gets bit, he begins to lose himself, leading to a terrifying tale of survival in a big, beautiful glass cliffside mansion. They get stuck between a chimp and a hard place. This is director Johannes Roberts' best film to date, which honestly isn't saying much. The plot is super simple, as is the character development. There are plenty of horror tropes that they actually lean into for humour. I would've liked more humour overall though. What I really enjoyed were the visual effects on display here. While the chimp was a combination of both practical and CGI, the gore was all practical, which looked great. This is a very violent movie. They do a good job showing just how powerful and brutal chimps can be. With a pretty solid pace, the tension is palpable for most of the 90-minute runtime. These are smarter than the average slasher characters. The use of silence and sign language is utilized very well here, especially with the addition of Kotsur. Happy he's getting work after his award-winning role in CODA. I was quite entertained. Overall, PRIMATE is prime serviceable simian silliness, a movie that knows exactly what it is, and what the audience is there for. If you're a sick freak like me and love violence in movies, I recommend it!

I had low expectations and expected death scenes to be cut aways, what we get is vicious, there aint no monkey-ing around! I'm not exactly sure how you could hate this movie...its a monkey running around going BANANAS on everybody...Yes there's typical dumb horror cliches, dumb characters, but it's still the best horror of 2026 so far. Lol i know the year just started, but started with a BANG...This Primate would destroy Art The Clown if Art is without the gun...so if you want to see Michael, Jason, Or Art the clown as a Monkey...go see Primate...This ain't No Monkey Business! Alot of it reminded me of Halloween...We get a closet scene like Halloween 78, and the monkey damm near even had his own Dr. Loomis just like Michael Myers...Also the tropical setting was amazing, I wish we had more scenery and scenes so we could wallow in it.

Primate is a deliberately restrained survival-horror film that prioritizes atmosphere and discomfort over spectacle. Rather than relying on constant jump scares or excessive exposition, the film unfolds slowly, allowing tension to build through implication, silence, and a growing sense that the situation is already beyond human control.
To be accurate for the movie score, I would give it a 6.8/10.
I'm sure there's a monkey business joke in here somewhere, but that's beneath me.

Primate was a VERY solid horror movie start off my 2026 with! The kills were brutal and utilized a lot of practical effects. One kill in particular was "jaw dropping". The score was surprisingly great and it elevated so many scenes. Ben is absolutely creepy in most of his scenes and the actor playing him did a great job. This film also gets pretty creative with how it builds tension in certain scenes. Especially the way it utilized the Father's deafness.

Like someone else says, if you don't take it seriously you'll enjoy it. I felt bad for the monkey though lol however the gore scenes were good. I went in and didn't expect much, didn't expect it to be great either but for a one time watch it's okay. I mean I'm glad it kinda skipped extra drama between teenagers which I expected first but I'd give 6(7)/10.

Primate has concepts of a creative idea however fails to deliver an enticing story. Filled with degradation to female intelligence and devoid of any common sense, the film works more to provide messy, unnecessary levels of gore in order to satiate those who are desensitized to gore, feeding the continuous need for more blood that is the new cycle of "horror".
Primate takes a simple creature feature setup and turns it into something far more emotional than expected.

Primate leans fully into its identity as a bloody, horror-driven experience, and for the most part, it succeeds. The core idea is intriguing, and the filmmakers execute it with a clear understanding of what horror audiences expect - tension, violence, and a steady stream of visceral moments.

If you don't take this film too seriously, you'll have a good time. While the performances are just serviceable and the writing is just alright, the film clips along nicely and the kills are pretty shocking, creative, and rather satisfying; it's darkly funny and satisfying to see facile and silly characters meeting their demises due to stupid decisions. The film is conscious of this sentiment, which makes it all the more fun. It doesn't take itself too seriously. The film knows what it is and leans into its own silliness.
It's entertaining. You know what you are getting into but if you have unrealistic expectations then you will be disappointed.

"Paper has fed me for 25 years. Honey, I have no other choice."
Park Chan-wook, master of black comedy, definitively already a living legend, delivers yet another masterpiece. So dark, so funny. The plot takes quite a while to fully kick in. But once it does, the film is unstoppably riveting. A flawless central performance from Lee Byung-hun, and fantastic turns from the rest of the cast.🔥

Park Chan-wook is widely regarded as one of the finest filmmakers working today. A versatile multi-talent, he has dabbled in a variety of genres, while leaving his own unmistakable authorial stamp on each. From the operatic revenge of 'Oldboy' and the rest of the so-called Vengeance Trilogy, to the melancholic machinations of 'Decision to Leave', and even the off-kilter eroticism of 'Thirst,' his films are united by an enduring fascination with obsession, violence and moral rot.

I can't believe that after watching worthless movies for so long and feeling sad that no one makes good movies anymore, I'm finally seeing a movie this good and well-made. I can't believe I enjoyed every single moment of it. I'm a harsh critic, but this movie touched me so much that I practically couldn't move while watching it. I would say that the most powerful part of this film is its story, as well as its black comedy that both makes the audience laugh and makes them think. It is so well-made and everything is in its exact place that I can't find any particular fault with it, although it wasn't without its flaws. The pleasure of watching this film completely captivated me and reminded me once again that South Korean cinema is one of the best in all the countries. I suggest that if you want to see this movie, watch it when your mind is not too busy and you can pay close attention to the movie and its very interesting and memorable events. This movie will create funny, heartbreaking, sad, happy, and even scary moments for you.
Watched at the 2025 Toronto International Film Festival.

I could speak about this film for hours and it still wouldn't be enough. Director Park Chan-wook delivers something both unique and deeply characteristic of his style. Paired with actor Lee Byung-hun, the two create a remarkable actor-director synergy, a chemistry that permeates the film from start to finish.

I went into No Other Choice with pretty high expectations, mostly because so many people kept comparing it to Parasite and other big Korean films. And honestly, you can feel the filmmakers really tried to make something meaningful. It's a very good-looking movie - sometimes even kind of breathtaking. The cinematography stood out the most for me: the lighting, the framing, the whole atmosphere. You can tell this wasn't done on autopilot or rushed.

Park Chan-wook delivers a witty, black comedy short that exposes the dehumanization of modern labor, blending humor and social critique in a visually precise, intelligent style. The film uses irony and paradox to highlight workplace contradictions, keeping audiences engaged while making a sharp commentary on contemporary work culture.

Haven't seen the original or read the book or anything so I can't say how original this movie is but it feels to me very Korean, so I think it was adapted very well to Korean sensibilities. It has some decent subtle humour, at least I myself didn't find it roaringly funny, but I thought it was smart that way.
Social media coaches haven't picked up on this employment strategy yet.

The film No Other Choice portrays the unfolding of a most improbable event-serial murder-arising inevitably from circumstances that could happen to anyone: aging, unemployment, family troubles. From the moment I stepped into the black comedy the writer and director intended, I couldn't take my eyes off the screen for nearly three hours of running time. Not a single scene feels wasted; every moment seems meticulously crafted, inspiring admiration for the care put into its making. The aesthetic beauty characteristic of director Park Chan-wook-his mastery of harmonizing mise-en-scène and music-permeates every dark corner of the film. The occasional bursts of sharp, ironic humor are also exceptional.

In an era where AI and robots are replacing labor, the value of human existence is rapidly diminishing, even threatening the very survival of craftsmanship and intangible heritage. This film captures, with both bitterness and irony, the unease that comes with the march of civilization. Park Chan-wook's signature mise-en-scène and artificial allure shine once again here, as he stages the inevitable dilemma of humans forced to point their guns at one another with a kind of chaotic humor. Among his filmography, this is arguably his most maximalist work, with a raucous ensemble of performances and sound design that gives palpable weight to the spaces they inhabit.

A story from a 1997 novel that has now been adapted twice into film, with its script centered around the paper business, but more focused on what a desperate man would do anything to provide for his family.. especially after being fired from his job, and the competition for such qualified individuals so fierce due to "corporate redundancy".

In 2025, we had Yorgos Lanthimos reimagining 2003's lesser known Save the Green Planet! (from South Korea) into an unforgettable piece of work, and the same year saw Park Chan-wook adapt (or reimagine) Donald Westlake's 1997 thriller novel The Ax into something bitingly funny, inarguably empathetic, and seethingly brutal ALL AT ONCE! That only goes on to show how once-attempted stories can always be RETOLD in fascinating ways when they're in hands of capable filmmakers. No Other Choice is a fantastic addition to Chan-wook's filmography, and amongst the greatest of his works.
"No Other Choice" is the latest from Korean director Park Chan-wook. I saw it in a film festival and assume it will be more widely available here in the States in the near future.

A frustrating viewing experience, overall. This is one of those movies that--while I can certainly appreciate the craftsmanship, visual stylization and acting on display--I just really didn't enjoy watching, at all.

Park Chan-wook has done good movies. He's done great movies. This is certainly not up there. The story seems to be a mish-mash of 'Parasite' and an old Michael Caine movie ' A shock to the system', but the story doesn't appear to be the problem here. Its the direction itself. The editing is no better. Just watch Handmaiden or OldBoy and you'll understand why we expect more from Park. Firstly the story takes too long to get set and shall we say a bit predictable. Black comedy needs the audience to be shocked or at least surprised and horrified at the outcome similar to some great skits on SNL..where the audience graon at the outcome. This is so predictable and mostly takes time to reveal even small surprises. The pacing is uneven and its a totally unsatisfying film by an auteur. His 'Decision to Leave' was slow but deliciously paced and interwoven and the shocks were ...shocks in the truest sense. The dude needs to take a break before his next film....because if 'Sympathizer' made by him was a bit flat and uninspired, this is no better. Time to recharge your batteries Sir !
I loved this movie. I've liked Park Chan-Wook's other films too. Some of them were excellent. This one is truly superb.
Nature, technology, family, and integrity in a delightful and stylish visual treat.
Dark comedies thrive on the delicate balance between drama and humour; it's a tightrope walk where tipping too far in either direction can derail the entire experience.

Deeply inspired by the tradition of French classic thrillers, particularly Claude Chabrol, No Other Choice is a beautifully shot dark comedy that will please the fans of Parasite. This absurdist human drama unfolds within stunning woody interiors, enveloped in a lush, menacing forest-green palette. I loved the bold colour choices throughout the movie.

No Other Choice dazzles as its director, supremely confident in his craft, weaves cinematic magic to tell the story of our time: What if we are really left with no choice, trapped in the cage we've built for ourselves?
What a stunning piece of art!

First off, I love a modern gothic horror adaptation, this just made my list of Halloween yearly rewatches along with Nosteratu (2024). There's just something about the visuals of rain flooded cathedral rooftops and blood flowing down cobblestone streets that gives you a faint touch of anxiety that you'll catch the plague while sitting in your theater's recliner.

Holy s***. Finally, after a bunch of okay, mediocre and awful adaptations tackling Mary Shelley's gothic science fiction horror epic, Guillermo del Toro gets to have his vision fully realized in what's easily one of the most faithful adaptations ever made while still being his own film.

Experienced Del Toro's latest on the big screen in 35mm print and was left speechless. The film is far from being compact in length but managed to present some of the best cinema of 2025, an expertly crafted culmination of multiple decades of experience from Del Toro.

The film succeeds best when it remains close to Mary Shelley's original such as in its storytelling approach and varying perspectives, as well as the dialogue and references that echo the novel. I wish there had been more of this. The book is rich in philosophy, psychology and tragedy.

Finally someone came very close to capturing the original story. Del Toro has done an excellent job. Perhaps not for everyone, but I was enthralled. I wish it was playing in main theaters but I imagine they are worried the general superhero and monster movie crowd won't get it. Personally, this was very worth my time.

I'm a massive fan of Guillermo's work. He's one of the only directors working in the film industry today that creates visual gothic feasts reminiscent of the movies I cherish from past decades. The colors, the lightning, the angles... he has it all.

This film is peak Guillermo del Toro. Stunning cinematography, good story and character development, and stellar performances from Oscar Issac and Jacob Elordi. I went into this film with low expectations, as many films in this genre are so predictable and underwhelming. This was not the case for this film. We got a whole new look at these characters and this story, without compromising the essence of what makes it familiar. Could we have just seen the rebirth of this classic cinematic universe?

It's no secret that talented and visionary director Del Toro has been working up the courage to complete Frankenstein, his biggest inspiration, for decades now. In interviews tailing many years he has told of his admiration for the story and it's effect upon him. Even some of his previous work has inspirations from the classic gothic novel, of course I'm referencing Blade 2 (believe it or not), where one of the reapers finally confronts his maker. And as a movie lover, nothing makes me happier than to see a director get to shoot his dream picture, especially a director who has contributed so much.

Simply a masterpiece. Oscar-caliber writing, directing, acting, costumes, makeup, cinematography, sound, editing, music, VFX and so much more. Every frame is gorgeous. Even though it's funded by Netflix, see it on the biggest screen possible. Truly a cinematic achievement. Kudos and congratulations to Guillermo del Toro and company. Astonishing, brilliant, redemptive, everything you would hope a movie to be.

Even though it didn't impress me that much, I can still respect the effort behind it. It's one of those films you watch once, enjoy a few parts, but you don't really feel like coming back to it. Solid attempt, but it just didn't click with me the way I expected, even though the concept had real potential.

I've long lost count of how many times I've written about Mary Shelley and Frankenstein, or how many different editions, spanning centuries, and how many formats of this story sit in my collection, from Blu-rays to DVDs and VHS tapes.
I was hesitant about going to see Frankenstein at TIFF (the plan was to wait until it hit cinemas) but I'm so glad I did. Thanks to a lovely friend I got tickets to the premiere!
While very different from the book in many ways, Frankenstein (2025) still delivers key plot points and emotional beats of the original novel in expert fashion.
With so many people praising this movie, allow me to offer this contrary opinion.

Guillermo Del Toro delivers a refreshing new take on one of the most famous horror stories of all time. Rather than crafting a typical horror film, he presents Frankenstein as an intimate and emotionally layered character study. Del Toro's deep affection for his "monsters" is once again evident - he consistently stands on their side, suggesting that the true monster is, in fact, Frankenstein himself.

Read the book in high school and loved it! This is the most faithful movie version in modern history. Though most definitely not fully accurate, I believe it carries a part of the spirit Mary Shelley intended. This movie will make you hate victor the way he deserves to be hated.
A visually beautiful, yet utterly unengaging movie. It reminds me of an elaborately decorated but empty eggshell-ey (pun intended).
What a film it was! I watched it from beginning to end completely captivated and thoroughly enjoyed every moment.

I was really looking forward to this but in the end I was disappointed by it. Why? Overblown and overlong by at least 30.minutes. Some of the deviations from the original story were just ridiculous such as giving Victor a prosthetic leg, making Elizabeth into a 17th century trouser chasing strumpet and making the monster into Superman. Talking of the monster, no, it didn't work did it? He looked like a member of Duran Duran that hadn't quite got his Halloween make up right.

GMO is a genius. The way he depicts generational trauma through the bond between Victor's father - Victor - The creature is beyond touching. The og by Mary Shelly is amazing, but I find myself genuinely in awe of GMO's version. He manages to capture the essence of the novel while keeping his unique tone. GMO shows the world with all of its usual cruelty and brutality, and at the same time, embraces those with love.
Firstly, hitting the negative as I found the prelude/exposition lengthy and slowly-paced. My fault, have just picked copy of shelf to reread and see what I was missing!
In 2020, we saw Gerard Butler struggle to save his family from a extinction level meteor strike by getting to a bunker in Greenland.

The first Greenland movie was fantastic. It was filled with emotion, action, and suspense. This felt like a completely different film. The movie picks up five years after the first one, and then the incomprehensible and impossible begins to happen over and over and over. It seems like the entire world is set on destruction, except for this one family that somehow finds its way Through circumstances that are just impossible and unfulfilling. The CGI was pretty bad at times as well. A big disappointment from the first one. If there's a third one, I will not be going to the theaters to watch.

A sequel is always hard. I think then director and producers did a good job with Greenland 2: Migration. They followed the original storyline well and even left room for a third movie. The message of fatherly strength was nice as was the message that strength requires trust and working together with others. There were certainly plots that could have made this movie even better (IMHO), but I was happy with movie ticket purchase.

The kid was denied in the first one as he was diabetic and some point asked about his numbers. 2nd one, grab the insulin was the thing said about it. Pretty sure that kid should not survived. Not once did they show him checking his sugars or giving himself insulin. Life of a diabetic is checking sugars and giving insulin. I do it everyday multiple times.

Gerard Butler's Greenland 2, "The Search For The Great Valley" (I'll also accept The Croods) is a classic survive-against-all-odds flick following the luckiest people on the planet, having made it through roughly 10 different life-threatening, low-survivability scenarios when most people wouldn't last 5 minutes.

Solid sequel with a different tone than the first one. Less large-scale destruction and more focus on survival, atmosphere and the journey. Not as intense as the original Greenland, but still engaging with good performances and some strong moments. If you go in with the right expectations, it's an enjoyable watch.
Greenland: Migration is the sequel to the first Greenland film from 2020. This follow-up is once again directed by Ric Roman Waugh, who also helmed the original.
I don't understand the hate. It's a disaster movie. What are people expecting, Shawshank Redemption 2? Its a movie about a world ending asteroid and everyone is crying about logic.. haha

I'm not one to pick apart sci-fi type movies. I watch for enjoyment and I think this was a good action/thriller. There were lots of moments where my stomach was clenched. If you liked the first movie, I'll say you'll enjoy this one. As a parent who is in bed by 9:30pm most nights, my wife and I came for the 9:05pm showing and had no problem staying awake.

So I had absolutely no idea about this movie and didn't even know that there was a film prior to this and I'm glad I didn't watch the original film and I'm sad to have sat though this. This movie just really isn't a whole los and it's really boring in my personal opinion and I just couldn't really find any of this story interesting. The best part of the film was definitely seeing all these random disasters just destroy everything and everyone in its path and that was definitely the most intriguing and best part of the film. The movie starts to lose me with its weird and bad writing and dialogue and some scenes just felt like they zoomed by so fast for some reason and I felt like this movie had like some of its runtime just cut because some of the scenes just skip to something new. I also found the characters to be not interesting and the acting was also quite bad the only character I found somewhat enjoyable was John played by Gerard Butler and I thought he had a decent performance in this film but I just don't think Nathan is a good character at all he's so annoying I don't know if it's just me but he was absolutely unbearable for me. There's some decent cinematography and CGI with the disasters but some of the CGI has me dying especially like the first disaster near the start of the film it looked too funny to me. I just don't know why this movie needed to be made it just doesn't offer anything new and feels like a blatant cash grab for a January release. I also found it odd how many useless side characters are in this film and the they legit end up killing them in a few minutes like what did they add to the story? It just felt completely useless to add all these boring and uninteresting characters to this family dynamic. I think the production design was actually good though and I really loved that aspect of the film because some moments looked absolutely great so shoutout to the production design team! Overall this is definitely a typical bad January release and I just didn't enjoy this and I wouldn't recommend this.

Greenland 2 picks up seamlessly where the first film left off and overall strikes slightly louder notes. The movie offers a bit more action without losing too much of the emotional core that already distinguished its predecessor. This by no means implies that the first installment was significantly worse. Rather, the sequel places a stronger focus on action and effects, though without going overboard. Overall, the second film feels to me a small notch stronger, mainly because more happens and the pace remains consistently higher.
